headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Tyson Foods Quarterly Investor Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] This call is being recorded. And if you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. I will turn now the call over to the Vice President of Investor Relations, J
componenttext: Welcome to the Tyson Foods Quarterly Investor Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] This call is being recorded. And if you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. I will turn now the call over to the Vice President of Investor Relations, Jon Kathol. Sir, you may now begin.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and thank you for joining us today for Tyson Foods' conference call for the first quarter of the 2016 fiscal year. On today's call are Donnie Smith, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Dennis Leatherby, Executive Vice President and Ch
componenttext:
Good morning, and thank you for joining us today for Tyson Foods' conference call for the first quarter of the 2016 fiscal year. On today's call are Donnie Smith, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Dennis Leatherby, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
Our remarks today include forward-looking statements as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations and projections. I encourage you to read the news release issued earlier this morning and our filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a discussion of the risks that can affect our business. 
Because our Annual Meeting of Shareholders takes place this morning, we'll need to end the call at the top of the hour to get to the meeting on time. [Operator Instructions] 
I'll now turn the call over to Donnie Smith.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jon. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us. Fiscal 2016 is off to a great start with record EPS of $1.15, up 49% over Q1 of '15's adjusted results. All of our segments performed very well, with Prepared Foods and Chicken producing reco
componenttext:
Thanks, Jon. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us. Fiscal 2016 is off to a great start with record EPS of $1.15, up 49% over Q1 of '15's adjusted results. All of our segments performed very well, with Prepared Foods and Chicken producing record operating income for the quarter, Pork had its second best quarter ever, while Beef showed significant improvement over Q4 and Q1 of '15. In total, we produced record operating income of $776 million at 38% over Q1 of last year. We had a record operating margin of 8.5% and record operating cash flows of $1.1 billion. 
Revenues were down due to the deflationary environment of raw materials and the divestiture of a few noncore businesses. Excluding the divestitures, sales volume was down just over 1% in Q1 as we sell more higher-margin value-added product, upgraded our mix to more profitable sales and processed fewer cattle. We're very pleased with the total synergies capturing $121 million in Q1. $61 million was incremental to Q1 last year, and we're on track to achieve more than $500 million this fiscal year. These synergies are a major source of funds for Prepared Foods growth. 
In the Prepared Foods segment, operating income was $207 million with a 10.9% return on sales, which was a record. Returns benefited primarily from declining raw materials and synergy capture. Volume for the quarter was down 7.7%, with pricing lower by 3.6%. The lower volume was the result of optimizing the sales mix by reducing product label products at retail and, to a lesser extent, the impact of avian influenza on our Turkey lunchmeat business and a slower-than-planned price reduction reflected on net retail shelves. 
For the balance of fiscal 2016, we anticipate continued savings on raw materials as well as synergy capture, and we'll invest a good portion of these savings into pricing, innovation and brand building. Our market outlook for Prepared Foods is near the low end of the 10% to 12% range. 
The Chicken segment produced record operating income of $358 million, with a record 13.6% return on sales. Volume for the quarter was down 0.5%, with 4.7% lower pricing. The slight sales volume decline in chicken again is a reflection of upgrading our mix. Results in the Chicken segment can be chopped up to solid execution. We're outperforming the industry and widened the GAAP. I believe we've demonstrated separation from the commodity players in large part due to the disproportionately high mix of value-added products in our portfolio as well as the production flexibly created with our buy-versus-grow strategy, which also reduces commodity exposure. Remember, on the last call, I broke out the categories how we sell chicken, and only 15% is pure commodity. 
As we continue to grow our value-added sales, produce less than we sell, execute extremely well and gain some benefit from lower grain cost, we now expect the Chicken segment margin to improve more than 11% for the year, up from our previous estimate of more than 10%. 
In the Beef segment, operating income was $71 million, with a 2% return on sales. Volume for the quarter was down 3.8%, while price was down 14.4%. Volume was down due to the Denison plant closure. Retail pricing has declined significantly, but beef is still expensive for consumers, with the beef-to-pork and the beef-to-chicken ratios at record levels. I'm pleased with a turnaround from the losses we sustained in Q4. Some of the improvement can be attributed to the mark-to-market and LCM from Q4. We got about half of it back in Q1, and the remainder will come over the next year or so. Better calcify in Q1, coupled with the realignment of our Denison and Dakota City plants, moderately improved our capacity utilization. 
We feel good about our Beef business, and the team is executing very well. Cattle supplies appear to be growing, and the recent semiannual Cattle on Feed report indicated the total inventory is up 3.2% over the previous year. However, there is still regional disparity in the location of the cattle. Q2 can be a little uneven due to the weather and consumption around [indiscernible]. We're going to remain conservative with our guidance of an operating margin at or above the low end of 1.5% to 3% normalized range. 
I'll add that I'm pleased about [indiscernible]. Our contingent was that it added incremental costs but no real consumer benefit. And now that it's been repealed, we're able to reduce the complexity our business when eliminating ground 800 SKUs. 
In the Pork segment, operating income was $158 million, with a 13% return on sales. Volume was down 2.2%, with pricing down 19.5%. Volume was down due to the divestiture of our Heinold Hog Markets business in Q1 of last year. Excluding this, Pork volume was up 5.5%. 
There were plenty of hogs on the market in Q1, Which lowered our call costs as well as our average selling price. With more hogs, we improved capacity utilization, which helped widen the margin spread. Our Prepared Foods segment benefits from lower pork material prices as well. 
We expect hog industry supply to be around 2% to 3% for the fiscal year, so we should be able to continue with the capacity utilization. We haven't seen any significant improvement in export markets. However, domestic pork demand is good. With near-record results in Q1, we are increasing our Pork segment outlook for the fiscal year, which should produce returns above 8%. 
Now let's move from the segments to our view of consumer demand. Lower gas prices and unemployment at the lowest levels since 2008 are translating into some growth into the perimeter of the grocery store number and more consumer spending on eating away from home. With the diversity of our portfolio, we're prepared to respond to these shifts in consumer behaviors. In the last 3 months, Foodservice traffic was up 1%, while checks-out was up 2%. While we play across all areas of foodservice, we're especially well-aligned with the categories in the national foodservice chains that are showing the most growth. 
On the retail side, overall grocery trips are down, but shoppers are spending more on our Core 9 product lines compared to total food and beverage and overall packaged meats. This is important because our Core 9 product lines are the primary drivers of sales and profitability within our packaged retail offering and includes brands like Jimmy Dean, Tyson, Hillshire Farms, Ball Park and Aidells. 
I'd like to the talk a little bit more about volumes, specifically at retail, and what you might be seeing reported by Nielsen and our IRI. Although to the top 10-branded food companies, including us, lost volume in calendar year 2015, our Core 9 product lines grew 1.2%. We are now seeing the price investments we've made begin to take hold, as sales volume was up 2% in the latest 12-week period but accelerated to a 4% increase in the latest 4-week comparison. 
I also want to point out that the Core 9 product lines, in aggregate, grew in Q1 ahead of the categories. In total, our share of these categories was up, and where our leading brands grew the most, the categories performed the best. Additionally, our volume growth improved through the quarter and on into January. I feel really good about our retail brands and expect to see the recent trends continue for the remainder of the year, as we see the full impact of pricing, recovery from AI and strong brand support. 
So all that's to say, a volume decline at a total Tyson level is an indicative of the health of our business, and I think the overall return we delivered in this quarter and the optimism around our outlook give us confidence for another record setting year, which is why we're raising our fiscal 2016 EPS guidance by 35% -- $0.35 on the low end to $3.85 to $3.95. 
We have a consumer-relevant portfolio packed with advantaged brands and advanced categories. We have superior supply chain. We have a high-performing team focused on execution. I like the position Tyson Foods is in. I like where we're headed, and I like the momentum that's building towards fiscal '17. Dennis?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Donnie, and good morning, everyone. Fiscal 2016 is off to a phenomenal start. We've been repeating over the past several years the value of our diversified portfolio, which has been evident in strong, steady returns. With our first quarter results
componenttext:
Thanks, Donnie, and good morning, everyone. Fiscal 2016 is off to a phenomenal start. We've been repeating over the past several years the value of our diversified portfolio, which has been evident in strong, steady returns. With our first quarter results, you can see our earnings potential when all segments performed well and finished within or above their normalized range us. With record EPS, record operating income and record operating cash flows, we were able to repurchase 6.4 million shares for $300 million in Q1. 
So far through the second quarter of this year, we've repurchased 3.9 million shares for $200 million. In total, over the past 7 months, we have now repurchased 16.2 million shares for $750 million. 
I'm also pleased to announce that yesterday, our Board of Directors increased the shares authorized for repurchase under this program by 50 million shares, underscoring our commitment to continue returning cash to shareholders. 
First quarter revenues were $9.2 billion, which is a decrease of 15% from Q1 a year ago, due to significant declines in beef, pork and beef prices. So smallest decline 7% as reported. However, when excluding the divestitures of the Brazil and Mexico chicken operations and the Heinold Hog Market business, our total company sales volume decreased 1%. Despite this small decline in volume, we are continuing to execute our strategy of growing in value-added categories, which is evident in our first quarter results. 
Total company return on sales was a record 8.5%. Operating income was a record $776 million, representing a 38% increase over adjusted operating income from Q1 a year ago. 
Our record earnings of $1.15 per share represents a 49% increase over $0.77 adjusted earnings per share in Q1 last year. 
I would also like to note that on an adjusted basis, our last 12 months EPS is $3.53. 
Our operating cash flow for the first quarter was a record $1.1 billion, and we spent $188 million on capital expenditures. This outpaced our depreciation by $37 million, as we continued to invest in projects with a focus on delivering high ROIC. 
Our effective tax rate in the first quarter was 35.2%. Net debt-to-EBITDA for the past 12 months was 1.7x, and on a gross debt-to-EBITDA basis, this measure was 2.1x. 
Including cash of $1.2 billion, net debt was $5.5 billion. Total liquidity was over $2.4 billion, significantly above our goal of $1.2 billion. Total liquidity at the end of the first quarter was enhanced by cash held for payments to livestock producers deferred to calendar 2016 as well as cash held for the retirement of $638 million in notes coming due in the second quarter. 
When these notes are retired, we will have paid down $2.4 billion of gross debt since the acquisition of Hillshire in August 2014. 
Our rapid leverage reduction in only 19 months reflects our commitment to maintaining investment-grade credit metrics. 
Net interest expense was $65 million during Q1. For the quarter, our diluted shares outstanding were $400 million. 
Now here are some additional thoughts on fiscal 2016. We now expect revenues of approximately $37 billion, which includes the impact of fiscal 2015 divestitures and expected declines in beef, pork and feed prices. We expect to capture more than $500 million of synergies in fiscal '16, which includes more than $200 million of incremental synergies over fiscal '15 from our Prepared Foods profit improvement initiatives and Hillshire brand synergies. 
Net interest expense should approximate $245 million. 
We currently estimate our effective tax rate to be around 35%. CapEx is expected to be $900 million, as we continue to focus on projects that will create long-term shareholder value. 
Prior to adjusting for any additional share repurchases subsequent to this call, and based on our average share price in Q1, we expect our diluted shares to be around 394 million. 
As we have demonstrated, our capital allocation priorities are governed by our disciplined focus on driving long-term shareholder value. Our priorities for deploying these significant cash flows that our operations generate are for growing our businesses organically through operational efficiency and capital expansion projects, along with investing in innovation and brand building; acquiring businesses that support our strategic objectives and returning to shareholders through share repurchases and dividends, all while maintaining plenty of liquidity, investment-grade credit ratings and continuing to expand our debt capacity. 
In closing, our Q2 should beat last year but will be less than Q1 due to our typical seasonality. And the third and fourth quarters are expected to be strong. As mentioned in this morning's release, we are raising our EPS guidance range to $3.85 to $3.95 for fiscal 2016, up from $3.50 to $3.65. This represents a 4-year EPS compounded annual growth rate of more than 18% annually. With each of our segments demonstrating tremendous overall performance, we view Q1 not as an exception but as a new foundation, which provides momentum for our continued growth. 
This concludes our prepared remarks. Operator, we're ready to begin the Q&A.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Mr. Brett Hundley from BB&T Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from Mr. Brett Hundley from BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Donnie, one question for you. A number of packaged food companies, both large and small, we've seen, have talked this earnings season about the macro becoming more challenging. Snacking has been one area highlighted in particular. And then conversely, it
componenttext: Donnie, one question for you. A number of packaged food companies, both large and small, we've seen, have talked this earnings season about the macro becoming more challenging. Snacking has been one area highlighted in particular. And then conversely, it looks like U.S. frozen categories seem to be improving some. Companies are also talking about the need to up brand support spend in an effort to contain volume deterioration. Your Prepared Foods volumes were down in the quarter, but you talked to the reasons behind that. Your profitability was solid. Can you give us your view of the Packaged Foods macro? You touched on it in your prepared remarks, but can you give us your view of the Prepared Packaged Foods macro from your vantage point? And within this question, can you specifically address this Core 9 effort that you're talking about this morning and how Core 9 insulates you not only within the broader macro, but also within packaged meat specifically?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, Brett. I'm going to try to take that like from snacking through frozen into the Core 9 to kind of give you the full feel. So not all snacking's created equal, right? What continues to grow in the snacking category is protein snacking. If I've got my
componenttext: Sure, Brett. I'm going to try to take that like from snacking through frozen into the Core 9 to kind of give you the full feel. So not all snacking's created equal, right? What continues to grow in the snacking category is protein snacking. If I've got my numbers right, total snacking's probably growing at around 6-or-so percent year-over-year. And as you know, that's a major focus for us in our innovation this year. Looking on into the frozen categories, breakfast and value-added poultry are 2 categories that are growing faster than total frozen and total food and beverage, and that's our key focus. But also look -- if you look at 84% of the refrigerated categories in which we compete are growing, and then 87% of the fresh categories in which we compete are growing, and it really reinforces our statement around having advantaged brands in advantaged categories. So now let me loop over into the Core 9. So if you look at the Core 9 brands or product lines really, those are so important because that's where we have the greatest value potential over the long term. Within the Core, we have the highest growth potential. We've probably got the strongest position with both consumers and customers and great margins. So that's why we focus, on what we call, the Core 9, and we spelled of those out in the last call because they are categories in which are growing faster than other refrigerated meats and faster than total food and beverage over the long term. And then we have advantaged positions within those categories.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Very clear. And then Dennis, I just had a follow-up question on liquidity use of cash. You touched on it there at the end. You're driving really strong cash flow right now. You do traditionally anyway. Your debt is in a very manageable position. You talke
componenttext: Very clear. And then Dennis, I just had a follow-up question on liquidity use of cash. You touched on it there at the end. You're driving really strong cash flow right now. You do traditionally anyway. Your debt is in a very manageable position. You talked about the notes in April. But getting outside of that, you've been choosing to repurchase a lot of shares here. And can you give us any insight into this strategy? Why the heavy share repurchase now? And how might -- you talked about some of your priorities for cash, but how might your priorities for cash change in months and quarters ahead?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thank you, Brett. As I said in my remarks, we do have $638 million notes coming due. We'll pay that off. We have more than $300 million of cattle and hog deferrals that we'll pay -- that we've already paid off. But you're right. We're throwing off a
componenttext: Sure. Thank you, Brett. As I said in my remarks, we do have $638 million notes coming due. We'll pay that off. We have more than $300 million of cattle and hog deferrals that we'll pay -- that we've already paid off. But you're right. We're throwing off a lot of cash, and it leaves with a lot of options. As we've been saying for the last year or so, we wanted to put ourselves in kind of an enviable position in that we wanted to maintain investment-grade ratings. We wanted to keep really strong debt capacity for M&A, which we do. And we have lots of capacity for M&A. And in the absence of that, if the right target doesn't come along that fits our strategy, then we're going to return cash shareholders while still growing organically through capacity expansion projects and investing heavily in our brands and innovation. So we really like where we're at. You can see us continue that.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Farha Aslam from Stephens Inc.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Farha Aslam from Stephens Inc.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a question on poultry. Your poultry margins were exceptional this quarter. And you spoke constructively about your outlook. Could you just give us a little bit more color about your thoughts around the second quarter? That is seasonally a bit weaker
componenttext: I had a question on poultry. Your poultry margins were exceptional this quarter. And you spoke constructively about your outlook. Could you just give us a little bit more color about your thoughts around the second quarter? That is seasonally a bit weaker in poultry, but the macro trends around poultry are getting better. Should we think your margins for the rest of the year, you're being very conservative with your 11% guidance?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I feel great about the second quarter. We're off to a good start. If I look at our mix, we continue to improve our value-added mix. We've got a lot of capacity to continue to grow in those areas. That gives me a lot of optimism to continue with a favor
componenttext: So I feel great about the second quarter. We're off to a good start. If I look at our mix, we continue to improve our value-added mix. We've got a lot of capacity to continue to grow in those areas. That gives me a lot of optimism to continue with a favorable outlook. It feels like to me that the categories, take retail frozen, is certainly growing. Retail frozen poultry is growing faster than frozen. And certainly, that category is growing faster than food and beverage. And it feels like we've fully overcome problems we had in the past and that we are back in business and growing. Our volume has been good in January. So feel good about that. And as I look forward to -- there's a couple of things that we still want to see. While we have quite a bit of our grain book, we don't have it all. So it's hard to paint the full picture for the year. But I do believe that the changes we've made in the portfolio, the changes we've made in the pricing strategy, certainly, the advantages that our supply chain gives us are creating a long-term view of much more consistent, stable earnings in our poultry business and in Prepared Foods and other parts of the business.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from David Palmer from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our next question comes from David Palmer from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question on -- the Beef segment, that was particularly impressive for us, given the fact that you're perhaps entering a cycle there. How are you thinking about -- perhaps go back and talk about how that margin happened with as much detail as you can. An
componenttext: A question on -- the Beef segment, that was particularly impressive for us, given the fact that you're perhaps entering a cycle there. How are you thinking about -- perhaps go back and talk about how that margin happened with as much detail as you can. And how are you now thinking about that -- the long term of that differently? Is that -- is the long-term future for that business really one where you're going to be bouncing around the low end of low single digits? Or perhaps can we think about that being a healthier margin business going forward?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let's talk a little bit about the quarter. So if you go back as far as Q3 when the feedlot started, extending the turns, if you will, and keeping cattle in the feedlot longer, coupled with the heifer retention and the reduction in cow slaughter that we
componenttext: So let's talk a little bit about the quarter. So if you go back as far as Q3 when the feedlot started, extending the turns, if you will, and keeping cattle in the feedlot longer, coupled with the heifer retention and the reduction in cow slaughter that we saw as the beginning part of the supply chain, the cattle operator began to effort to expand the hard, cattle supply dried up and strained margins. So as we moved out of Q4 into Q1 in -- there were some regional disparity, but overall, the feedlots began to market both cattle and become more current, if you will, with the inventory the have in the feedlot. That provided us the supply we needed to be able to improve our margins. Plus, if you remember back at the end of Q4, right in the last couple of weeks or so in the quarter, we had a lower cost of market adjustment and a mark-to-market adjustment that we made. And so we got about half of that back in Q1. Now the rest of that will keep coming back to us as we progress on through the year because you had beef sold out front, and then you bought live cattle feed against the hedges. So put all that together, we're kind of in the, well, 2% sort of towards the low end or getting towards the middle of that range. As we look forward, Q2 is always a tough quarter for us. You got a lot of weather issues around, as we're seeing this week, up in the Midwest. [indiscernible] is just kind of a low demand for beef, particularly. We want to get through that. Feels like after Easter, should see cattle supply improving in the back half also to improve. I think, longer term, our beef margins should stay within that 1.5% to 3% range. We feel good about that.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is really about the capacity utilization side, and I know you had some major comparisons in Q3. I'm just wondering, longer term, if these margins can be built upon and maintained. Is there anything about these recent developments that make you think
componenttext: This is really about the capacity utilization side, and I know you had some major comparisons in Q3. I'm just wondering, longer term, if these margins can be built upon and maintained. Is there anything about these recent developments that make you think significantly different about the longer term for Beef?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, David. So I guess, my hairline would be, look, the worst is over in terms of the cattle supply. We expect, I don't know, 3%, 3.5% cattle supply increase in the back half of the year. And you should see -- it's a little bit hard to tell at the very beg
componenttext: No, David. So I guess, my hairline would be, look, the worst is over in terms of the cattle supply. We expect, I don't know, 3%, 3.5% cattle supply increase in the back half of the year. And you should see -- it's a little bit hard to tell at the very beginning of a herd rebuilt, but you should see something on the order of 1% to 2% more bed cattle available per year, I think, for the next 2, 3 years. And so as the supply of cattle improves, then we should see our margins improve as well. So that's the reason for the confidence in our outlook that Q1 is not an aberration. Now remember, Q2 is going to be Q2, but looking at it over the year, I'm comfortable that we should be in the range that -- of the 1.5% to 3%.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Adam Samuelson of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Adam Samuelson of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to start to pick up on something, Dennis, that was at the end of your prepared remarks. And you talked about this quarter being a new foundation for future performance rather than a peak. And I wanted to maybe follow up on Farha's question a little
componenttext: I want to start to pick up on something, Dennis, that was at the end of your prepared remarks. And you talked about this quarter being a new foundation for future performance rather than a peak. And I wanted to maybe follow up on Farha's question a little bit on the Chicken business in particular because the margins here are very strong and now running well above your normalized range of 7 to 9. And I'm trying to think about what would be the drivers of margins going back to that normalized range if you remain confident on the value-added mix, and the operating momentum that you have and maybe think about that trajectory a little bit.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great question. We feel very good about our Chicken business. It's really set up well. It's largely a pull business from 85%, 90% pull business. We've got our mix set up straight. We are in the position where we can grow even more, especially in the furth
componenttext: Great question. We feel very good about our Chicken business. It's really set up well. It's largely a pull business from 85%, 90% pull business. We've got our mix set up straight. We are in the position where we can grow even more, especially in the further processing side, take advantage of oversupply situations where we can buy meat really cheap, put a nice spread on it. So in our tray pack business with the conversion of our plant in South Georgia is really starting to take off at an even higher level, and we're just going to continue to improve our value-added mix over time.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. That's very helpful. And then maybe going on to this Core 9 concept. And a, I was hoping, can you  talk about the Prepared Foods and Chicken also sales are driven by the Core 9 at this point? And the second, maybe a little bit more color by cat
componenttext: All right. That's very helpful. And then maybe going on to this Core 9 concept. And a, I was hoping, can you  talk about the Prepared Foods and Chicken also sales are driven by the Core 9 at this point? And the second, maybe a little bit more color by categories and areas of inflection that you've seen the sausage in particular, I think, has improved in the last couple of scatter periods, but a little bit more detail by category.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. So when we look at our Core 9, I was going to run through that real quick. We're really talking about Hillshire Farm Smoked Sausage, Aidells smoked sausage, Hillshire Farms lunchmeat, Jimmy Dean frozen breakfast sausage, and then our Core-brand
componenttext: Yes, sure. So when we look at our Core 9, I was going to run through that real quick. We're really talking about Hillshire Farm Smoked Sausage, Aidells smoked sausage, Hillshire Farms lunchmeat, Jimmy Dean frozen breakfast sausage, and then our Core-branded bacon then, Ball Park hotdogs, our retail value-added poultry and then State Fair and Ball Park Corn Dogs. So those are what we call the Core 9, where we have a disproportionate ability to grow faster than the categories, and they're very meaningful categories. So if I look at -- and what we've really been focused on is the recent trends in our volume versus the category volume. We were -- I think I mentioned in my comments. I think I said that we were able bit slow in seeing the price declines reflected at retail. And now through the last 4 weeks or so, we've pretty much seen the pricing get reflected on the retail shelf, and volume is responding. If I looked at, say, Smoked Sausage, in the last 4 weeks, our volume growth is up 4% versus -- that's the last 4 weeks versus 2% for the 52-week and 2% for the 12. And last week, it was up double digits, like 10% or so. If I look at Jimmy Dean Breakfast Sausage, for example, we're up 2% in the latest 52, but 11% in the latest 4-week comparison. And that's what we've been looking for to see momentum in volume as we see the price reflected on the shelves. So we feel really good about the core of our business. Also let me -- one on hotdogs real quick. We did see a little bit of impact, I think, from our HRT announcement in hotdogs. But we are seeing a response there. We feel great about the brand support for the summer grilling season, and we're really, really anticipating a very, very strong grilling season this year. So I feel great about that. Hope that helps.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Ken Golden from JP Morgan.
componenttext: And the next question comes from Ken Golden from JP Morgan.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: When I look at retail margins on Chicken, Beef and Pork, at least as implied by USDA data, they are very strong right now kind of across the board. And we're seeing some indication, I guess, of minor slippage in those retail prices, but not a whole lot. S
componenttext: When I look at retail margins on Chicken, Beef and Pork, at least as implied by USDA data, they are very strong right now kind of across the board. And we're seeing some indication, I guess, of minor slippage in those retail prices, but not a whole lot. So I'm curious, from your perspective, and what are your expectations for meat prices on shelf going forward? Are you seeing any indication they'll really start to fall further from here, which could help your volumes going ahead?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's hard. It's really hard during this time of the year to get your best feel for what retail meat prices are going to do through the year because next week, we're going to enter into Lent, and it's just a difficult season to protect -- to predict prices
componenttext: It's hard. It's really hard during this time of the year to get your best feel for what retail meat prices are going to do through the year because next week, we're going to enter into Lent, and it's just a difficult season to protect -- to predict prices. But if you just look at the macro fundamentals, right, we've got the lowest unemployment we've had since '08. We got really cheap gas prices, and that is returning disposable income to the consumer. And we are seeing traffic up a little bit at Foodservice, not a lot, and we're not expecting a whole lot, but we are seeing the -- a movement to the perimeter of the store, which is where we have great strength. So I'm optimistic that the consumer will respond well to what should be fairly favorable prices. If you look at the supply cattle coming to market, the hogs coming to market, supply chicken's in the market, you should have resembled pricing structures, and certainly, pricing structures that would allow us to continue first.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then my other question is you're guiding to a pretty significantly bigger benefit from feed cost than you did 3 months ago, I think. But I a look at corn and meal, I'm not seeing most of a change over that time in spotter future's prices. I mean
componenttext: Okay. And then my other question is you're guiding to a pretty significantly bigger benefit from feed cost than you did 3 months ago, I think. But I a look at corn and meal, I'm not seeing most of a change over that time in spotter future's prices. I mean, the sum, but not a huge amount. So maybe you talked about this and I missed it, but I'm just curious what striving this degree of change in your outlook for feed.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we had about -- I think it's round numbers, 100 -- Dennis, $100 million change from our previous quarter's guidance to this one?
componenttext: Yes, we had about -- I think it's round numbers, 100 -- Dennis, $100 million change from our previous quarter's guidance to this one?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if you look at just corn futures all Q1 long, and I think meal features, too, the market just continued to decrease. We stayed really short, and we're able to just basically buy this. We ship it or price it as we ship, it and that allowed us to have a
componenttext: And if you look at just corn futures all Q1 long, and I think meal features, too, the market just continued to decrease. We stayed really short, and we're able to just basically buy this. We ship it or price it as we ship, it and that allowed us to have a cheaper cost structure. And when we talk about, by the way, our outlook, we're talking about what's in cost of goods. So we feel good about how our year's going to shape out. We've got quite a bit, not all, but enough to feel very comfortable about our cost structure in chicken already priced throughout the year. So feel good about that.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Mr. Robert Moskow from Credit Suisse.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Mr. Robert Moskow from Credit Suisse.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: One of the reasons I've been skeptical on Tyson and maybe others, too, and obviously very wrong, is that the thinking that the chicken cycle would end up by turning and hurting the business. But you're seeing two things this year in your guidance, or I am
componenttext: One of the reasons I've been skeptical on Tyson and maybe others, too, and obviously very wrong, is that the thinking that the chicken cycle would end up by turning and hurting the business. But you're seeing two things this year in your guidance, or I am, is your feed costs are better, so that's a reason to take up the number. But you're obviously benefiting from the lower chicken costs, commodities as well. Is there -- can you give us a little bit of more color on the extent to which the lower commodity chicken costs helped you in the quarter and how that is factored into your guidance for the year?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Rob, I'd -- well, not knowing what chicken prices are going to be for the rest of the year, it'd be hard to quantify for the year. But I can give you very good feel. We -- during Q1, we probably bought on the order of 75 loads a week of poultry raw m
componenttext: Yes, Rob, I'd -- well, not knowing what chicken prices are going to be for the rest of the year, it'd be hard to quantify for the year. But I can give you very good feel. We -- during Q1, we probably bought on the order of 75 loads a week of poultry raw materials, maybe more than that. But say, round numbers. And we're buying that meat well below $1 instead of selling it well below $1. Plus, with our buy-versus-grow strategy, we don't have that excess leg quarter. So we're selling fewer leg quarters today. And I've been here long time. I can't ever remember us selling fewer leg quarters than we are today. And buy-versus-grow certainly  plays a part of that. But with great innovative capabilities, we're finding ways to upgrade that raw material into value-added, high-margin opportunities, and that's a real key. So when you combine strength of our value-added portfolio, the strength of our brands, both fresh and frozen, when you look at the diversity of the portfolio between small bird and value-added and fresh, and then you combine that with this great marketing and innovation engine that we've got, it really does help stabilize the earnings of our Chicken business over time. It's not the same Chicken business that it was a few years ago.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's very clear. And then a follow-up on Prepared Foods and the Core 9. I guess your guidance really hasn't changed that much even though, as you said, the volumes are starting to improve on your Core 9. Are you expecting volume growth in the Prepa
componenttext: Yes, that's very clear. And then a follow-up on Prepared Foods and the Core 9. I guess your guidance really hasn't changed that much even though, as you said, the volumes are starting to improve on your Core 9. Are you expecting volume growth in the Prepared Foods segment for the rest of the year? Can we expect to see a very strong volume number in second quarter? Or is it going to be kind of negative for a while and then eventually kind of lap the challenges in turkey in the back half?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. You should expect growth. We are very intent. And obviously, with raw materials where they are, with synergy capture we have, we have the dry powder we need to get the pricing right, to drive growth, to support these brands, to drive growth where we h
componenttext: No. You should expect growth. We are very intent. And obviously, with raw materials where they are, with synergy capture we have, we have the dry powder we need to get the pricing right, to drive growth, to support these brands, to drive growth where we have it. As a matter of fact, we're increasing our investment in innovation to drive long-term growth in these brands. And the early week -- during November and December, frankly, we didn't get the price realization on the shelf that we needed to drive volume. During the month of January, the pricing gaps were reflected on the shelf, and we saw the volume response that we were looking for. So I feel great about our growth going forward for the year. We have advantaged brands and advantaged categories, and we fully intend to take advantage of that because that's what the consumer wants us to do. So -- and you're right, we will be lapping the AI problems. We've got to get some points of distribution back, but we're -- we've got great sales team, working on that. We continue to improve the mix. One of the volume issues in Q1 was that we didn't repeat some private label volume. And frankly, it's like, I don't know, spiral-sliced hams and private label bacon. And we just have so much more opportunity in branded consumer pull categories that it was the right thing to do for our business and for the customer to not repeat those very low, if not negative version in private label sales and improve that into a [indiscernible].

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Donnie, I get all that, but sales down 11% in the first quarter. If you can help us model out what you think the sales growth for Prepared Foods this year. Are you still down because of the private label decisions? Or are you going to go back to positive
componenttext: Donnie, I get all that, but sales down 11% in the first quarter. If you can help us model out what you think the sales growth for Prepared Foods this year. Are you still down because of the private label decisions? Or are you going to go back to positive pretty quickly here?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think you're going to see positive sales growth as well, absolutely. We've got to get the volume to support the lower pricing to get the total dollars up. But yes, we're headed that way. Sorry, I misunderstood your question.
componenttext: No, I think you're going to see positive sales growth as well, absolutely. We've got to get the volume to support the lower pricing to get the total dollars up. But yes, we're headed that way. Sorry, I misunderstood your question.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Akshay Jagdale from Jefferies.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Akshay Jagdale from Jefferies.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let me ask about the chicken margin sustainability in a different way as well. Obviously, you outperformed what the commodity markets did in our estimates by about 1,000 basis points. So I think what I'm seeing is, and just help me if I'm wrong here or
componenttext: So let me ask about the chicken margin sustainability in a different way as well. Obviously, you outperformed what the commodity markets did in our estimates by about 1,000 basis points. So I think what I'm seeing is, and just help me if I'm wrong here or if I'm reading it incorrectly, but relative to the market, your portfolio is more stable higher-margin products. And that's starting to play through on the revenue line. And clearly, this quarter, we saw that, right? And I think what we're seeing clearly is big bird segment, if I may, where you're taking a lot of this cheap meat out of the big bird plants and adding value to it. That's been a great strategy. So my question really is more on the retail tray packs side of your business and potentially on the small bird side. Can you talk about the sustainability of the margins on those 2 sort of subcategories? Like a lot of people think your tray pack business is not as -- it can't maintain these margins at these levels if supply increases, right? So if you look at 3 segments for the chicken market, it seems to me that whatever supply increase has been coming into the market, it's been on the big bird side. So what happens if and when the retail tray packs supply, industry-wise, increase it? What does that do to your margin structure? And then similarly, on the small bird, I mean, I know it's not happening right now, right? We know that there's no new capacity coming in on those 2 segments. But just  help me think through that for a second.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. So first of all, as evidenced in South Georgia, we have the flexibility within our supply chain to move our mix to where the consumer's going. If you look, at a macro view, all the recent volumes because at fresh, for example, because you've go
componenttext: Yes, sure. So first of all, as evidenced in South Georgia, we have the flexibility within our supply chain to move our mix to where the consumer's going. If you look, at a macro view, all the recent volumes because at fresh, for example, because you've got so much pork, price is way down, and pork demand's up. But in general, remembering that chicken is twice the size of the category of both -- of beef or pork, chicken demand is really good, and it over indexes to the millennials as they enter the workplace and begin, in earnest, consuming foods. So we feel great about the macro trends and where they're leading us. We have the flexibility within our supply chain to move within small birds, fresh, whatever we might do. Certainly, it's not our business model to oversupply big bird. We'd rather buy that meat and [indiscernible], as you mentioned. I think about our business to remember is we got the #1 fresh branded retail. We've got great penetration across a broad segment of customers nationally. And we have phenomenal quality service and innovation. So I feel good that we will remain the leading fresh supplier as we move out front, whether it's a small bird into the retail deli or fast food cutup, or whether it's at retail, plus we've got a lot of innovation that we can continue to innovate in these fresh categories, and our customers rely on that. So I think that is a big portion of what stabilizes our fresh chicken business, if you will, for the future.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Just on Prepared Foods. How much of the revenue guidance cut is related to, let's say, the Prepared Foods business not doing as well as you thought previously? And then your margin guidance on Prepared Foods, although pretty solid, in light of the $
componenttext: Okay. Just on Prepared Foods. How much of the revenue guidance cut is related to, let's say, the Prepared Foods business not doing as well as you thought previously? And then your margin guidance on Prepared Foods, although pretty solid, in light of the $250 million commodity tailwind and the roughly $200 million incremental synergies, seems a bit light. I think what it means is you're spending or planning on spending a lot of money on brand building. But why do that when sort of volumes, if you look historically last 12 weeks or so, haven't been as robust?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I'm going to start kind of at the back end and work my way back up, is that the reason the volumes haven't been as robust as we want them to be in our Prepared Foods has really got -- there's really 2 things in that. It depend -- number one, it d
componenttext: Okay. So I'm going to start kind of at the back end and work my way back up, is that the reason the volumes haven't been as robust as we want them to be in our Prepared Foods has really got -- there's really 2 things in that. It depend -- number one, it depends on your view of everything that you look at in Nielsen IRI about our data because there's 2 categories that if you do the kind of the macro view of everything, Tyson and IRI, you've got 2 categories in there that would be I have chicken, and then the UPC ground beef chubs also show up. So the 1 and 3-pound rolls of ground beef. That, which is a huge portion, by the way, of the volume decline or use proportion of the volume decline, that meat's going fresh. And frankly, for us, if the consumer would rather have that breast meat in a fresh tray versus having it done and IQF back, we're going to go where the consumer is because, frankly, if margines is up a little bit, same thing on the ground beef. If they'd rather have it, that volume not in the EPC but in a non-UPC tray, we're going to do that. So first of all, we're that in my. A better question, the big revenue issue overall for the company really comes in 3 places. Beef and pork commodity prices are down a lot. And then the other thing is the divestitures of the Mexican business, the Brazilian business and our hind hold hog markets business. So that is the overwhelming majority of the revenue decline quarter-over-quarter and is driven primarily by beef prices and, by the way, will be for the year. So well, we would expect it to be for the year. Does that help?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. But just -- I know that a  vast majority going from $41 billion to $37 billion is those 3 issues. But is it fair to say, Prepared Foods, you are expecting lower sales than you previously were? And how much so roughly?
componenttext: Yes. But just -- I know that a  vast majority going from $41 billion to $37 billion is those 3 issues. But is it fair to say, Prepared Foods, you are expecting lower sales than you previously were? And how much so roughly?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I don't think it's fair to say that. Now in our Prepared Foods business, about half of it is Foodservice, and those do use pricing formulas, and the deflation in the raw materials does take some of the pricing down, but it doesn't affect margin. If yo
componenttext: No. I don't think it's fair to say that. Now in our Prepared Foods business, about half of it is Foodservice, and those do use pricing formulas, and the deflation in the raw materials does take some of the pricing down, but it doesn't affect margin. If you look at the retail business, we are seeing the response that we want to receive from the pricing and the brand support that we're given these brands. And we we will continue to do that all year because we've got a great opportunity for us.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from Michael Piken from Cleveland research.
componenttext: And your next question comes from Michael Piken from Cleveland research.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: If we could just shift over to Pork. There's been a lot of talk about the sustainability of the chicken margins [indiscernible]. Just wanted to get sort of your thoughts as we sort of move through the year on pork. And in particular, could you stay at the
componenttext: If we could just shift over to Pork. There's been a lot of talk about the sustainability of the chicken margins [indiscernible]. Just wanted to get sort of your thoughts as we sort of move through the year on pork. And in particular, could you stay at these elevated margins if the export markets pick up?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we do have one always kind of on the export markets, and we're not seeing a lot of improvement in that yet. Could still happen. If it does, it's certainly upside. If you look at the macro picture, you're probably going to have somewhere on the order ab
componenttext: So we do have one always kind of on the export markets, and we're not seeing a lot of improvement in that yet. Could still happen. If it does, it's certainly upside. If you look at the macro picture, you're probably going to have somewhere on the order about 2% to 3% more hogs for the year. We should have really good capacity utilization. I feel good about where we are in terms of where the hogs are, so it should competitive there. So I feel good about margins. And certainly, it's a little bit too early to predict what might have been in the back half of the year. But yes, it feels like we've got a good pork year coming. Certainly off to a great start.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. Yes. Maybe if I ask it a little bit in a different manner. I mean, I guess, obviously, the export outlook is a little bit more uncertain. But I mean, just judging by how you did in the first quarter, should we sort of think about the rest of
componenttext: Okay, great. Yes. Maybe if I ask it a little bit in a different manner. I mean, I guess, obviously, the export outlook is a little bit more uncertain. But I mean, just judging by how you did in the first quarter, should we sort of think about the rest of the year as being, if the hog availability is still strong and domestic demand kind of remains very this, everything else, you said kind of above 68%, but I mean, is it double-digit 10% possible for the year? Or what are we sort of generally looking at? Because there's a lot of room between above 68% what you did in the first quarter.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, there is. And I think Q1 in hog is always strong, and I wouldn't want to predict the whole year based on Q1. But it feels very good to us that it should be a pork year.
componenttext: Yes, there is. And I think Q1 in hog is always strong, and I wouldn't want to predict the whole year based on Q1. But it feels very good to us that it should be a pork year.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Patrick Chairman from BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Patrick Chairman from BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Patrick in for Ken. Just a question about Prepared Foods. Just wondering how long will the reinvestment of all synergies will go on? Seems like it's been I guess holding your margins back trying to figure out what the timing is to margins will imp
componenttext: This is Patrick in for Ken. Just a question about Prepared Foods. Just wondering how long will the reinvestment of all synergies will go on? Seems like it's been I guess holding your margins back trying to figure out what the timing is to margins will improve on these levels, especially with chicken margins kind of potentially doing better than Prepared Foods this year.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so with advantaged brands in advantaged categories, we're really built for growth. We've got a great innovation pipeline that we're investing in for the long term. And so there's always a balance, right, between margin and growth. And our intent is t
componenttext: Yes, so with advantaged brands in advantaged categories, we're really built for growth. We've got a great innovation pipeline that we're investing in for the long term. And so there's always a balance, right, between margin and growth. And our intent is to make sure that with the advantages that we have, that we continue to grow. Frankly, the retailers depend on us to grow these categories, and we're going to continue with strong brand support. We spend a lot of time understanding the consumer and using those insights to build the right kind of innovation pipeline for the future. And so we'll always balance growth and margins. Obviously, in Q1, we didn't get the growth that we wanted, and the reason we didn't get the volume growth we wanted, we didn't get prices reflected on the shelves in the time that we had predicted so that our price gaps would be right. That is now fixed or pretty much fixed. And I think you're going to see the volume growth that will support the overall dollar of margin growth over time.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Patrick, from my perspective, what I like with what I'm seeing is our vitality index numbers are really strong, and that's a good sign for that volume growth in the years ahead. That really excites us to keep that margin solid and growing.
componenttext: Patrick, from my perspective, what I like with what I'm seeing is our vitality index numbers are really strong, and that's a good sign for that volume growth in the years ahead. That really excites us to keep that margin solid and growing.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our last question comes from Ms. Diane Geissler from CLSA.
componenttext: And our last question comes from Ms. Diane Geissler from CLSA.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have a question. So the guidance range for this year, if we exclude the extra week last year, is sort of 22% to 25%. And I guess, when I look at it, I mean, look, fresh meats had a $1, leg quarters are $0.25. You're going to have margins in the Chicken
componenttext: I have a question. So the guidance range for this year, if we exclude the extra week last year, is sort of 22% to 25%. And I guess, when I look at it, I mean, look, fresh meats had a $1, leg quarters are $0.25. You're going to have margins in the Chicken segment above -- we above the top end of your normalized range. So as we look into fiscal '17, I appreciate we don't know what's going to go with pricing, et cetera, but it seems to me that with the way the chicken business is set up now, you should be able to sustain margins above the top end of the normalized range. And therefore, earnings of next year should be up 10% plus. Am I thinking about that wrong?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Diane, we are very optimistic about this year and the foundation that we built for next. I mean, if you look at it next year, we've got more synergies coming. I think we're going to prove in the next few weeks in the quarter so that we're -- we've got gre
componenttext: Diane, we are very optimistic about this year and the foundation that we built for next. I mean, if you look at it next year, we've got more synergies coming. I think we're going to prove in the next few weeks in the quarter so that we're -- we've got great brands that are well positioned. I think protein demand is going to remain pretty strong. I know we have great consumer relevance. I'm not -- it's really hard to predict what input prices will be a year from now or whatever, but if you just look at the macro view, it feels pretty good that they'll be reasonable and, certainly, within our ability to manage, should have plenty of supply of livestock. We've got a great innovation pipeline, great cash flow, as Dennis talked about. If I look at -- anyway. So yes, we're really optimistic.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I guess the short answer is we can make money when breast meat is at $1, and we can also make money when breast meat is at $2?
componenttext: Okay. So I guess the short answer is we can make money when breast meat is at $1, and we can also make money when breast meat is at $2?

componenttext: Yes, we can.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016

componenttext: That is the takeaway?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Feb 05, 2016
