headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Tyson Foods Quarterly Investor Earnings Call. Today's conference is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to Jon Kathol, Vice President of Invest
componenttext:
Welcome to the Tyson Foods Quarterly Investor Earnings Call. Today's conference is being recorded. If you have any objections, you may disconnect at this time. [Operator Instructions] 
I will now turn the call over to Jon Kathol, Vice President of Investor Relations. Sir, you may now begin.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Tyson Foods Incorporated Third Quarter Fiscal 2016 Earnings Conference Call. On today's call are Donnie Smith, Chief Executive Officer; Tom Hayes, President; and Dennis Leatherby, Executive Vice President and Chief Financi
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Tyson Foods Incorporated Third Quarter Fiscal 2016 Earnings Conference Call. On today's call are Donnie Smith, Chief Executive Officer; Tom Hayes, President; and Dennis Leatherby, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
Tyson Foods issued an earnings new release this morning, which has been filed with the SEC on Form 8-K and is also available on the Investor Relations section of our website at ir.tyson.com. 
Our remarks today include forward-looking statements as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These statements reflect current views with respect to future events such as Tyson's outlook for future performance on sales, margin, earnings growth and various other aspects of its business. These statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations and projections. I encourage you to read the release issued earlier this morning and our filings with the SEC for a discussion of the risks that can affect our business. 
During the call, there will be a discussion of some items that do not conform to U.S. generally accepted accounting principles, or GAAP, including adjusted EPS. Tyson has reconciled these items to the most comparable GAAP measures in the earnings release and on our website at ir.tyson.com. [Operator Instructions] 
I would like to remind everyone that this call is being recorded on Monday, August 8, 2016, at 9 a.m., Eastern Time. A replay of today's call will be available on Tyson's website approximately 1 hour after the conclusion of this call. This broadcast is a property of Tyson Foods, and any redistribution, retransmission or rebroadcast of this call in any form without the expressed written consent of Tyson Foods is strictly prohibited. 
I'll now turn the call over to Donnie Smith.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jon. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us today. We continue to build momentum. Our differentiated business model and our strong performance across all segments are contributing to higher, more stable margins. We delivered record th
componenttext:
Thanks, Jon. Good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us today. 
We continue to build momentum. Our differentiated business model and our strong performance across all segments are contributing to higher, more stable margins. We delivered record third quarter earnings, operating income and return on sales, and as a result, we're raising fiscal 2016 adjusted earnings guidance to $4.40 to $4.50 a share. 
Synergies for the quarter were $150 million or $63 million incremental over Q3 of '15. Year-to-date, synergies totaled $415 million, with a $191 million incremental versus the same period last year and will exceed the $500 million target as planned. We bought back 6.6 million shares in Q3 and another 5.4 million so far in Q4, bringing our total shares repurchased to just over 31 million during the past 12 months.
Q3 was an outstanding quarter and what will be a record year. And now Tom Hayes, who's on his first earnings call as our new President, will report on our operating segments.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Good morning, everybody, and thanks a lot, Donnie. I'm really excited to be on the call and looking forward to a lot of interaction, more interaction, with our investors and analysts and in addition to leading our amazing team. As Donnie said, I'
componenttext:
Great. Good morning, everybody, and thanks a lot, Donnie. I'm really excited to be on the call and looking forward to a lot of interaction, more interaction, with our investors and analysts and in addition to leading our amazing team. 
As Donnie said, I'll take you through the segments and provide color around the results as well as some initial thoughts on 2017. 
First, let's look at Prepared Foods segment. Operating income in the third quarter was $197 million, with a 10.9% operating margin. Volume compared to Q3 last year was up 1.9%, and sales dollars were virtually flat. The lower average selling price resulted from decreased raw material costs and successful pricing strategies to drive volume. We're particularly pleased with the volume increases in Ball Park hotdogs, Hillshire Farm Smoked Sausage and lunchmeat. 
In Q3, we captured $116 million in synergies in the Prepared Foods segment, with $37 million incremental to third quarter last year. As we look towards 2017, we expect Prepared Foods to remain at the lower end of the 10% to 12% operating margin range, as we continue to invest heavily in innovation, new product launches and supporting the growth of our leading brand. 
Turning to the Chicken segment. Chicken produced operating income of $380 million, with a 13.9% return on sales. The important call-out in chicken is that we've continued to improve our product mix. We've grown value-added sales by 5% and reduced commodity sales by 10%, which is why the average selling price was up 40 basis points in the quarter, where our volume was down 90 basis points versus the same quarter last year.
We're being really strategic about our growth. We're growing where we want to grow, and it's reflected in our record return on sales. We've restructured our Chicken business to produce higher, more stable margins over time. And as a quick reminder, here's how we've done this. 
First, we've optimized our cost structure by investing in our operations, with good ROIC projects and by taking out more than $1 billion of inefficiencies from our systems. Second, we've diversified our pricing mechanisms. Third, we've upgraded our mix to more value-added, branded products to meet demand from our retail and foodservice customers. Fourth, we've implemented the buy-versus-grow strategy. And finally, we're providing industry-leading quality and customer service day in and day out. 
We expect to finish the fiscal year with an operating margin of more than 12% in the Chicken segment, and we think fiscal 2017 will be similar. 
Turning to the Beef segment. Operating income was $91 million, with a 2.4% return on sales compared to a $7 million loss in the third quarter last year. Volume was up 2.9% as more cattle were available to process, while the average selling price declined 14.6%.
Although we expect fed cattle supplies to increase 2% to 3% in fiscal 2017, domestic availability should increase only slightly due to reduced imports and some export demand improvement. 
Finally, in the Pork segment, we had another great quarter, with $122 million in operating income and a 9.6% return on sales. This compares to $64 million and a 5.3% return in Q3 of '15. 
Despite increased production, volume was down 1.7% due to reduced inventories as well as product mix changes. The average selling price was up 7.2%. Our Pork segment should finish fiscal 2016 with an operating margin above 10%, and in 2017, it should be above its 6% to 8% normalized range. 
So overall, we expect supplies of chicken, beef and pork to be up 2% to 3% next year. However, domestic demand for protein has been strong. We expect it to continue as prices decline. We'll stay focused on growing sales volume and shifting our mix to more value-added products. And we have the unique ability to access multiple channels to meet consumer and customer demand wherever food is sold. This allows us to drive growth and remain a preferred provider with leading brands. 
I'm going to turn back it over to Donnie, who's going to expand and give us his thoughts on the macro environment.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Tom. I want to build on what Tom said about growing where we want to grow. Consumer sentiment is mildly positive as unemployment and gasoline prices have decreased, while real GDP and disposable personal income have moved up slightly. In t
componenttext:
Okay. Thanks, Tom. I want to build on what Tom said about growing where we want to grow. 
Consumer sentiment is mildly positive as unemployment and gasoline prices have decreased, while real GDP and disposable personal income have moved up slightly. In this environment, foodservice traffic remains about flat, and average check size is up about 2%. QSR change, which typically drive demand for value-added chicken and Prepared Foods, are showing the most growth. We're well-aligned with those national account customers as well as other growing channels in Foodservice. 
At retail, efforts to support our brands are paying off. Our Core 9 volume is up 6% for the 13 weeks ended July 24, and our retail fresh volume continues to grow as consumers shift towards the perimeter of the store. 
We partner with our customers to grow their businesses, which is why our retailers rely on us as category captains for consumer and category insights. Since Tyson and Hillshire came together 2 years ago, we've more than doubled our category captaincies with retailers to the total of 143. Innovation also plays a key role in customer growth and, therefore, ours. Our Vitality Index, which measures the percent of sales from products launched within the previous 3 years, is projected to exceed 21% for foodservice and 13% for retail this fiscal year. Those rates are considered best-in-class and include new products like Hillshire Farm chicken Apple sausage for convenient stores, cleaner label, all-natural chicken for foodservice distributors, Jimmy Dean potatoes hashbrowns and Ball Park frozen meat for retail and club stores. 
We're on track to launch Tyson Tastemakers in e-commerce in the fall and, later this month, Tyson naturals, frozen value-added chicken and new varieties of Hillshire Snacking will roll out at retail. 
Our differentiated capabilities in both our scalable supply chain and customer and consumer demand expertise are driving profitable growth in the marketplace. We see this across the key metrics, including the category captaincies and the product Vitality Index that I mentioned earlier. And we expect this to continue as we have the organizational capacity and the resources to drive growth and higher, more stable margins.
Through our strong sales team, we continue to foster strategic customer relationships and leverage our consumer insights, innovation, culinary expertise, service and quality to grow with our customers, develop channels and build brands that will propel us forward. Obviously, we have a lot to be excited about as we finish fiscal '16 and move into fiscal '17, which we expect to be another record year and another year of growth. 
Now I'll turn it over to Dennis, who will report on the quarter and give you some early thoughts on next year.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Donnie, and good morning, everyone. Q3 was another great quarter, as we delivered record earnings due to strong results across each of our segments. The investments we have made in our brands and optimizing mix across the entire portfolio has be
componenttext:
Thanks, Donnie, and good morning, everyone. 
Q3 was another great quarter, as we delivered record earnings due to strong results across each of our segments. The investments we have made in our brands and optimizing mix across the entire portfolio has been evident in the growth of our earnings in 2016. Being a growth company, we see tremendous value in our shares. In Q3, we were able to repurchase 6.6 million shares for $425 million. So far, during the fourth quarter of this year, we've repurchased over 5 million shares for $380 million. In total, since August of last year, we have repurchased over 31 million shares for just under $1.8 billion at an average price of about $56 per share, which underscores our commitment to continue returning cash to shareholders. 
Total company return on sales was 8.2%, a record for our third quarter. Operating income was $767 million, representing a 35% increase over adjusted operating income from Q3 a year ago and also a record for the third quarter. 
Our record third quarter EPS of $1.25 represents a 51% increase over $0.83 per share in Q3 last year. On an adjusted basis, Q3 EPS of $1.21 was also a record and a 51% increase over last year as well. It's important to note that on an adjusted basis, our last 12 months EPS is $4.26. 
Our operating cash flow through 3 quarters was $1.9 billion, and we spent $515 million on capital expenditures. This outpaced our depreciation by $55 million as we continue to invest in projects with a focus on delivering high ROIC. Our effective tax rate in the third quarter was 31.8% and 33.9% on an adjusted basis. 
Net debt-to-EBITDA for the past 12 months was 1.7x. Including cash of $197 million, net debt was $6 billion and total liquidity was $1.3 billion. Net interest expense was $58 million during Q3. For the quarter, average diluted shares outstanding were 388 million. 
Now here are some thoughts on full year fiscal '16 and some early thoughts on fiscal '17.
We expect revenues of approximately $37 billion for fiscal '16 and growth in revenues for fiscal '17. Net interest expense should approximate $245 million in fiscal '16 and $225 million in fiscal '17. We currently estimate our adjusted effective tax rate to be around 34.8% for fiscal '16 and 35% for fiscal '17. 
In fiscal '16, CapEx is expected to approximate $725 million. In fiscal '17, we expect CapEx to increase as we continue to focus on projects that create long-term shareholder value.
Prior to adjusting for any additional share repurchases subsequent to this call, and based on our average share price so far in Q4, we expect our average diluted shares to be around 381 million. 
Our last 12 months adjusted ROIC is 17.5% and is expected to be over 18% by the end of this fiscal year. This is approaching our pre-Hillshire acquisition ROIC of 20.5%, which further illustrates not only the strength of our earnings power but also our commitment to create incremental shareholder value.
We generated a record $2.8 billion in operating cash flow these past 12 months, which we used to invest in our over $730 million in CapEx projects; retire $638 million in notes, which matured in Q2 at coupon of 6.6%. We also returned approximately $200 million in dividends to our shareholders and repurchased over 31 million shares for just under $1.8 billion, including repurchases so far in Q4. 
So far, in fiscal '16, each segment is operating within or above their normalized ranges. The strong performance of each of our segments gives us confidence to raise our adjusted EPS guidance to a range of $4.40 to $4.50 for fiscal '16. This new range is 40% over our fiscal 2015 adjusted EPS and represents a 4-year CAGR of 22%. And while we stay focused on wrapping up a record year for fiscal 2016, we expect growth in sales, operating income and EPS in fiscal 2017, as we believe the Chicken segment should be over 12% again; Prepared Foods margin should be near the low end of its normalized range of 10% to 12% as we continue to invest heavily in innovation, new product launches and the growth there of our brands; our Pork segment should be above its normalized range of 6% to 8%; and the Beef segment should be toward the upper end of its normalized range of 1.5% to 3%. 
In closing, the evolution of our business model to produce strong, stable margins has set us up for another record year. The bar is set high for 2017 as we've come off 40% EPS growth in fiscal '16, but we are excited about the momentum we are generating, which gives us confidence to achieve high signal-digit growth for fiscal 2017. 
This concludes our prepared remarks. Tony, we are ready to begin Q&A.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We have our first question from Mr. David Palmer.
componenttext:
[Operator Instructions] 
We have our first question from Mr. David Palmer.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Clearly, fiscal '16 is going to be a big year, and obviously, that needs difficult comparison that you mentioned. You also mentioned that you expect growth in next year, but [indiscernible] that 10% plus, which, for you, has been a long-term annual target
componenttext: Clearly, fiscal '16 is going to be a big year, and obviously, that needs difficult comparison that you mentioned. You also mentioned that you expect growth in next year, but [indiscernible] that 10% plus, which, for you, has been a long-term annual target. How are you thinking about fiscal '17? And specifically, what are the key variables in your mind that will help or hurt you with regard to getting back or getting another year of growth or maybe even that 10% next year?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Sure, David. Let me take that one. So it's early. So if the question is, is it possible to do better than high single digits, let me put it this way. With what I know today, I'm very confident in saying high single-digit EPS growth. Potential is ther
componenttext: Yes. Sure, David. Let me take that one. So it's early. So if the question is, is it possible to do better than high single digits, let me put it this way. With what I know today, I'm very confident in saying high single-digit EPS growth. Potential is there for more, so the short answer is yes, we can. Keep in mind, as you mentioned, that is coming off a year of EPS growth over 40%, and as Dennis mentioned in his comments, like 4-year compounded growth rate of 22%. So here's the way we're thinking about how '17 is shaping up. So in Prepared Foods, we're now seeing really solid volume gains across foodservice and retail just like we thought we would when we got our price gaps right, when our merchandising took effect, when our advertising hit. And of course, we're driving really strong innovation, as I mentioned in our comments. So we feel really good about the momentum we have now and taking that through back-to-school into our fiscal '17. Our Chicken business is -- it continues to do great. We continue to value up our mix, as Tom mentioned in his comments. And we continue to drive out inefficiencies from the business. So I think Chicken looks it's set up to have another good year of very solid growth and great earnings. In Pork, as we look at that segment, we hear a lot and it's true that there is more capacity coming online. But we see that capacity coming late in calendar '17, probably more affecting our '18 than our fiscal '17. And we do see about 2%, maybe a little bit more increase in hog numbers out there. So there's going to be plenty of hogs around. And typically, when the supply is good, then that means another good year for us, and that's certainly what we're expecting. Similar story in Beef. Beef supply continues to grow. We think the fed supply will be up about 2% to 3% next year. Fed supply is moving. We think that the increase will be probably felt greater in the North, which probably benefits us a bit. And then on top of all that, David, we've got the ability, great cash flow, and we'll be returning a lot of cash to shareholders and buybacks. So that's why we continue to have a lot of confidence about '17. We feel very good about upper single digits now. And certainly, if there's more there, we're going to get it.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: A quick follow-up to that is, and I think it really is a controversy or at least a question in people's minds is, how much is, let's say, an issue of controllables versus noncontrollables? For instance, in the Chicken segment, you have controllables such
componenttext: A quick follow-up to that is, and I think it really is a controversy or at least a question in people's minds is, how much is, let's say, an issue of controllables versus noncontrollables? For instance, in the Chicken segment, you have controllables such as your mix of value-added chicken, maybe even the small birder mix and buy versus grow. But there are other cyclical factors like corn prices or whether those small, midsized bird prices continue to hold up. How are you thinking in terms of what is controllable and what is perhaps a big macro variable?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let me -- I want to address the grain thing, and I'd like Tom to address the controllables versus noncontrollables and how we view that. So if we look next year at what the forward curve and the corn in the market is giving us, it looks like the next y
componenttext: So let me -- I want to address the grain thing, and I'd like Tom to address the controllables versus noncontrollables and how we view that. So if we look next year at what the forward curve and the corn in the market is giving us, it looks like the next year is going to be pretty much flat to this year. So we feel good about the way next year is structured. I don't want you to say -- I don't want to do think, though, that corn prices necessarily determine our chicken margins. We've diversified a lot of our pricing strategies, which Tom will talk about in a second, to be able to insulate us from that, and that's really been our story. Tom?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'd just say, David, in the prepared remarks, we talked about model, how it's changing in Chicken. And we're getting more specific about this because obviously, it's a huge driver of value. Where we want to grow, we are growing really successfully in
componenttext: Yes. I'd just say, David, in the prepared remarks, we talked about model, how it's changing in Chicken. And we're getting more specific about this because obviously, it's a huge driver of value. Where we want to grow, we are growing really successfully in both retail and foodservice in the Chicken business. And what offsets that are the categories where we don't want to grow. So leg quarters, by-products, that's a part of our business that we just aren't focusing on. And we actually have been doing great internalizing more of leg quarters for our own use on first quarter of value-added products. So as Donnie said, the pricing mechanism, that's a huge driver for us. We've been doing a lot of work on that. And so continuing to drive value-added should give you the confidence. We'll continue to talk about that. You'll see that in the numbers. It turns into the right margins. We're focused on volume and margin and executing buy versus grow and continuing to focus on innovation, value-added service, quality. That's the answer. That's where we're going.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have our next question from Mr. Tim Ramey.
componenttext: We have our next question from Mr. Tim Ramey.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Donnie, it seems to me that you're sort of kind of one acquisition of away from getting this company to where you might want it to be, more solidly in the double-digit EBITDA margin camp. I think you've done 2 quarters now of double-digit EBITDA margins,
componenttext: Donnie, it seems to me that you're sort of kind of one acquisition of away from getting this company to where you might want it to be, more solidly in the double-digit EBITDA margin camp. I think you've done 2 quarters now of double-digit EBITDA margins, which is incredible relative to history. How would you react to that comment? And what does the lay of the land look like for M&A?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Tim, the great thing about our business is how much organic growth opportunity we have. Protein is obviously very important to consumers, not just in the U.S., but around the world. So it's great to be a protein-centric company. And then when you look
componenttext: So Tim, the great thing about our business is how much organic growth opportunity we have. Protein is obviously very important to consumers, not just in the U.S., but around the world. So it's great to be a protein-centric company. And then when you look back categories that we're in and how consumers are shifting demand, for example, more towards fresh, more towards value-added, seeking more convenience, that kind of thing, that just plays into our wheelhouse because that's what we do. When you layer on top of how the consumer is shifting, our ability to understand the insights and how you use those insights to drive innovation, those are really key building points to continue in this organic growth story. Of course, we're going to be focusing, as Tom mentioned, on growing at both retail and foodservice and value-added poultry and in Prepared Foods. Of course, we've got all the raw materials back behind that we need, and we can continue to work on ways to add value to those. So there's just a great organic growth story there. Now I'll turn it over to Dennis a little bit and let him talk about our capacity. But certainly, our M&A strategy is all around, first, strategic fit, then making sure that, that target can provide the type of return that we're looking for. And then we also look at the execution and the cultural fit of that kind of target. So Dennis, you want to talk about capacity and such?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the good thing about what's going with our strong cash flow and our deleveraging, even though we're largely keeping that flat since March, is that our debt capacity has expanded to a point where we could easily do a Hillshire-size acquisition so l
componenttext: I think the good thing about what's going with our strong cash flow and our deleveraging, even though we're largely keeping that flat since March, is that our debt capacity has expanded to a point where we could easily do a Hillshire-size acquisition so long as it's at the right price, we can create the right synergies and generate, drive returns. So we're really in good shape there.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sounds good. So you don't need M&A but M&A could be a positive for the future.
componenttext: Sounds good. So you don't need M&A but M&A could be a positive for the future.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sir. That's a great way to look at it.
componenttext: Yes, sir. That's a great way to look at it.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have our next question from Mr. Adam Samuelson.
componenttext: We have our next question from Mr. Adam Samuelson.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe some questions in Prepared Foods, if you don't mind. Maybe first, the guidance for the year of margins at the low end of the normalized range. You're 10.9% exactly for the first 3 quarters. So can you maybe bridge how margins are actually down year-
componenttext: Maybe some questions in Prepared Foods, if you don't mind. Maybe first, the guidance for the year of margins at the low end of the normalized range. You're 10.9% exactly for the first 3 quarters. So can you maybe bridge how margins are actually down year-over-year in the fourth quarter with synergies and lapping some of the AI issues last year? And then with the synergies that you should have incrementally in '17, can you scope kind of -- it seems like a really big step-up in new product innovation and marketing spend there, but help scope some of the spending bridge for '17 in Prepared Foods.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. It's Tom. So what I'd say, as it relates to this quarter, there is a bit of noise. We had some plant closures that are rolling through the numbers. But the biggest item is that we are investing to grow the business. As we talked going back seve
componenttext: Yes, sure. It's Tom. So what I'd say, as it relates to this quarter, there is a bit of noise. We had some plant closures that are rolling through the numbers. But the biggest item is that we are investing to grow the business. As we talked going back several quarters ago, we had [indiscernible] we're trying to resurrect the volume that we had sort of previous to a lot of the input price declines, input cost declines, and we've done it. The growth has been substantial at our Core 9. So the theme is we're going to continue to invest. We're going to make sure that we have the position on the shelf. I think '17 is setting up to be a year where there's going to be a lot of protein available. We want to make sure we have the right shelf position. And innovation, as you called out, is going to be significant. So for the quarter, I'd say there's a bit of noise, but it's really reinvestment we put in the business and showing the volume results. As we look to '17, it's really more of the same. We're going to continue to invest and drive growth, particularly through innovation. And we'll talk a lot more about that in the future quarters about how that's setting up, what you should expect.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe just a follow-up in the pork market. There's been some volatility in kind of hogs and bellies and hams in the last couple of weeks. I would agree that market's setting up pretty favorable for the back half of this year. But can you ta
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe just a follow-up in the pork market. There's been some volatility in kind of hogs and bellies and hams in the last couple of weeks. I would agree that market's setting up pretty favorable for the back half of this year. But can you talk about the market volatility that you're seeing in the pork market and some of those values of late?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Same volatility you've seen, Adam. I mean, of course, belly prices have dropped precipitously and that kind of thing. And what we do is we just stick to our plan. There's a good supply of hogs coming our way. We've got great business out in front of
componenttext: Yes. Same volatility you've seen, Adam. I mean, of course, belly prices have dropped precipitously and that kind of thing. And what we do is we just stick to our plan. There's a good supply of hogs coming our way. We've got great business out in front of us to add value to those raw materials, which we do. We'd love to see export markets a little bit than what they are, but I think, over time, that could help a little bit. We don't really use -- we said years ago, we don't really use the freezer as a customer, and we don't -- we have a plan for physical hedges on bellies. We continue to execute that plan. And then the raw material favorability will work its way in through the pricing over time. Foodservice reacts a little faster than certainly the retail does. But ultimately, the raw material cost will find its way back to the customer. So yes. Echo the volatility, we're weathering it just fine. We're getting into a better demand period, certainly, then what we've come through. So we feel good about our Pork business on through '16 and then another really, really solid year in '17.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have our next question from Ms. Farha Aslam.
componenttext: We have our next question from Ms. Farha Aslam.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can we talk about Chicken? And you highlighted the value-added. Is that improvement coming more in foodservice, more in retail, Tyson brands? Can you give us more color on where that benefit's coming from?
componenttext: Can we talk about Chicken? And you highlighted the value-added. Is that improvement coming more in foodservice, more in retail, Tyson brands? Can you give us more color on where that benefit's coming from?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Farha, it's Tom. What we've seen is both in retail and foodservice. The answer to your question is more in retail. Overall, consumer products, so food that Tyson sells to consumer, retail stores. Otherwise, we have been -- year-over-year, we're doin
componenttext: Sure. Farha, it's Tom. What we've seen is both in retail and foodservice. The answer to your question is more in retail. Overall, consumer products, so food that Tyson sells to consumer, retail stores. Otherwise, we have been -- year-over-year, we're doing great. We have had fantastic year-over-year growth as it relates to Chicken specifically. That's where the largest benefit is coming from. The Chicken business in foodservice is strong and, I would say, getting stronger. So the -- it's not -- we don't want to make either-or decisions because all that business is very profitable to us, and we talk about value-added, if you think about our retail and foodservice businesses collectively, that's what we mean, so primarily products that we're focused on. And so it's been in this quarter, I would say, more retail benefit, but looking forward, I think we're going to be well-balanced in both channels.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. Just circling back on Beef. Your commentary and Beef, particularly for next year, is probably the strongest I've seen it in years. Is that sustainable for a longer period of time than just kind of going into next year, given the cattle cyc
componenttext: That's helpful. Just circling back on Beef. Your commentary and Beef, particularly for next year, is probably the strongest I've seen it in years. Is that sustainable for a longer period of time than just kind of going into next year, given the cattle cycle tends to be long? Can you give us more color on what is your largest segment in terms of sales?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So a couple of things about the -- so it looks like the next year's fed supply will be up, I think, a little better than 2%, maybe even approaching 3%, but certainly somewhere in that area. And if you look out another 2, 3 years past that, you can co
componenttext: Yes. So a couple of things about the -- so it looks like the next year's fed supply will be up, I think, a little better than 2%, maybe even approaching 3%, but certainly somewhere in that area. And if you look out another 2, 3 years past that, you can count on the same thing but maybe borrow -- barring another drought like we had 3, 4 years ago. So it looks like, to us, that the fed supply will continue to increase. And as the fed supply continues to increase, that, certainly having more cattle available to process, improves our business. There's another thing that, I think, helps us with our outlook or feel more and more positive about our outlook on Beef, and that is the continued growth of our Case Ready offerings. Coming up in, I believe, it's October, there is a new regulation on retailers around having to keep up with where the raw material comes from as they ground ground beef back of house. And I think that portends a future for our Case Ready grounds business. We've certainly been in a lot of conversations, and we have the capability to do a lot more of that business than we're doing today. So that could also help improve our beef margins over time. So we got a solid outlook and feel very, very good about that part of the business.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have our next question from Mr. Akshay Jagdale from Jefferies.
componenttext: We have our next question from Mr. Akshay Jagdale from Jefferies.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can you talk just about Beef a little bit? So this quarter, relative to what we see in the sort of industry spreads, which are tracked by various sources, your performance is still lagging after 4, 5 years of outperformance. Pretty consistently, last coup
componenttext: Can you talk just about Beef a little bit? So this quarter, relative to what we see in the sort of industry spreads, which are tracked by various sources, your performance is still lagging after 4, 5 years of outperformance. Pretty consistently, last couple years and a quarter, they've not been as good. I'm guessing that's all related to the international markets where you have a greater share. So tell me if I'm thinking about that correctly. And second, are you expecting that to reverse next year in your sort of guidance commentary? Or will that be even an upside factor?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Akshay, so certainly, the export factor is a part of it. We do over index, particularly into Asia. And with the drop credit being down some 15% or 20% versus a year ago in those markets, been a little softer than we'd like them to be. And certainly, the v
componenttext: Akshay, so certainly, the export factor is a part of it. We do over index, particularly into Asia. And with the drop credit being down some 15% or 20% versus a year ago in those markets, been a little softer than we'd like them to be. And certainly, the value's going to those markets going a little softer than we'd like them to be. That has affected us versus the competitive set. But there's another factor I think that needs to be weighed in. If you look at the regional disparities in, let's call it, southern region of cattle procurement in the northern region, we way over index in terms of our slaughter capacity in the north and cattle in the south have been about $1, 100 weight, so somewhere in the order of $8 ahead cheaper than cattle had been in the north. We think that, that will change over time at some of the smaller feedlots that tend to be in the north closer to the grain begin to increase capacity as the supply of cattle increases. So we think that favors us going forward, certainly, from where we have been. So I think those are the really the 2 biggest factors. Our plants are running great, our efficiency, all the stuff that Steve and his great group are doing to manage the business are in good shape. Those environmental factors are what they are, and we'll continue to manage them over time.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just one longer-term question, which is related to 2 segments, Prepared Foods and Chicken. So you mentioned organic growth opportunities. I feel like the biggest opportunity long term is to improve the branded mix and sort of the margin mix, if I
componenttext: And then just one longer-term question, which is related to 2 segments, Prepared Foods and Chicken. So you mentioned organic growth opportunities. I feel like the biggest opportunity long term is to improve the branded mix and sort of the margin mix, if I may. So can you give us an update on sort of Core 9, where you stand, the volume performance? Obviously, it was a big turnaround, so that's positive. But over, like, a 3- to 5-year period, like, where is your Chicken business relative to where you think it could be from a branded mix and a margin mix perspective?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thanks, Akshay. It's Tom. Yes. So think about the way that we are going or have grown the Prepared Foods business, the retail branded portion, the same approach is going to be applied to and starting to be applied to the Tyson brand. So -- in Chicke
componenttext: Okay. Thanks, Akshay. It's Tom. Yes. So think about the way that we are going or have grown the Prepared Foods business, the retail branded portion, the same approach is going to be applied to and starting to be applied to the Tyson brand. So -- in Chicken. So overall, speaking to the Core 9, we have, like I said, a lot of innovation in the pipeline. There's a lot of good things that are already out there in the marketplace, the Jimmy Dean hashbrowns, Jimmy Dean frittatas, Hillshire Snacking platform. Hillshire Snacking is going very well, by the way. So it's going to be definitely on the back of innovation. There is no question about that. And climbing back to the Chicken segment, your question in particular, we see there's going to be a plenty of opportunity for us to drive growth in areas that, right now, are -- there hasn't been a lot of innovation. You think of the fresh tray pack chicken, it's been relatively static for years and years, and we like that opportunity for us to continue to think about how it can be different. And so I'd expect you to expect that our innovation efforts against the entire portfolio of Chicken and Prepared Foods will deliver some significant benefits. And we'll be talking, like I said, more about that in the future quarters here, but we're applying the same model in terms of marketing innovation, the Chicken, as we have historically, to the Prepared Foods business.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have our next question from Mr. Ken Goldman.
componenttext: We have our next question from Mr. Ken Goldman.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask about the Other segment. I know it's not the biggest segment. I realize it's hard to forecast. But I think you're guiding to another loss of roughly $90 million or so next year. I think maybe investors were hoping for something a little bi
componenttext: I wanted to ask about the Other segment. I know it's not the biggest segment. I realize it's hard to forecast. But I think you're guiding to another loss of roughly $90 million or so next year. I think maybe investors were hoping for something a little bit better than that. So can you just update us a little bit on the longer-term outlook for this segment and what the strategy might be for here?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'll let Dennis comment on some of the other. I'll comment on some of the other. So let me talk about China in general, in particular. So our China business continues to improve over expectations year-over-year. As Sally and the team work to shift ou
componenttext: Yes. I'll let Dennis comment on some of the other. I'll comment on some of the other. So let me talk about China in general, in particular. So our China business continues to improve over expectations year-over-year. As Sally and the team work to shift our strategy from being a customer-centric strategy to be more of a consumer-centric strategy, we're seeing that, that long term will provide, we think, significant value. And she has a new general manager in China in place, a new sales lead in place. We've got a very, very strong team in China, and I'm very optimistic about their ability to continue to improve over time. I will say, though, that the dynamics in that market are very difficult. Corn and soybean meal are significantly higher in China than they are here in the United States. And the wholesale markets, we're still somewhat beholden to the wholesale markets because we haven't made a full switch into value-added at retail yet. So the wholesale markets continue to be weak and quite a bit weaker than we would have thought the wholesale pork market would have indicated. Usually, those 2 markets move in concert. The wholesale pork market has moved up, and chicken has not moved up near as fast as the wholesale pork market has. So very difficult operating environment but the team's doing a great job strategically turning that business. There are some other stuff, and I'll let Dennis address that.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Ken, what also is in Other is kind of that bucket of expenditures that doesn't necessarily apply to segments. For example, merger and integration costs have been there. And to a lesser degree, we also have our SAP activities. We have one launch or
componenttext: Right. Ken, what also is in Other is kind of that bucket of expenditures that doesn't necessarily apply to segments. For example, merger and integration costs have been there. And to a lesser degree, we also have our SAP activities. We have one launch or in the process of another upgrade over the next year, so you will see some of those costs in there as well.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. And my follow-up, and I'll be honest, I've been jumping back and forth from calls, so just cut me off if it has been asked already. But I think you reduced the tailwind for raw materials to your Prepared Foods segment to 240 to 300. I
componenttext: That's very helpful. And my follow-up, and I'll be honest, I've been jumping back and forth from calls, so just cut me off if it has been asked already. But I think you reduced the tailwind for raw materials to your Prepared Foods segment to 240 to 300. I was a little surprised by that, just given what we've seen in hog and pork prices lately and how precipitously they've fallen. I realize the segment's a lot more than just those 2. But maybe could help us understand what's driving less of an input benefit to that segment, that'd be useful.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I don't know specifically that we were assuming the exact same thing. I would say, Ken, for our Prepared Foods business, a lot of the pricing, we have input cost deflation that flows through pricing in a pretty significant way. We try to, of course,
componenttext: Yes. I don't know specifically that we were assuming the exact same thing. I would say, Ken, for our Prepared Foods business, a lot of the pricing, we have input cost deflation that flows through pricing in a pretty significant way. We try to, of course, continually decrease trendline margins over time. But that's going to whatever benefit we would see, there's a large part of that, that flows straight through to pricing reduction. So whatever movements that we would see up or down, that's our intent. And like I said, trying to make that less volatile over time in terms of our earnings is all about brand investments, innovation investment and continuing to drive the agenda there. And that's sort of the way we think about fluctuations in commodity cost inputs through the Prepared Foods business.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, we'll have Jon din in a little deeper on your question. He can follow up a little later today, okay?
componenttext: Tim, we'll have Jon din in a little deeper on your question. He can follow up a little later today, okay?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have our next question from Mr. Michael Piken.
componenttext: We have our next question from Mr. Michael Piken.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to dig a little bit deeper into Prepared Foods and just trying to understand when we might expect to start to hit the top end of the range as looking couple of years out. What types of things would you be looking forward to reach the top end?
componenttext: Just wanted to dig a little bit deeper into Prepared Foods and just trying to understand when we might expect to start to hit the top end of the range as looking couple of years out. What types of things would you be looking forward to reach the top end? And at what point do you sort of start to parse where your brand spending initiatives have been more successful than others?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Michael, it's Tom. We haven't set guidance as it relates to where we think we're going to hit the top end. What we have done is really spent a lot of time on what our innovation pipeline is setting up as. I would say not just in retail, also in fo
componenttext: Yes. So Michael, it's Tom. We haven't set guidance as it relates to where we think we're going to hit the top end. What we have done is really spent a lot of time on what our innovation pipeline is setting up as. I would say not just in retail, also in foodservice. And we like where we sit today. At 10.9% and sitting out sort of the lower end of the range for us is the right spot to be right now, given the investments that we're seeing with those investments in the business. As it relates to where we start to hit the ceiling, we have a different MAP objective, marketing advertising promotional spend, by brand and some of their our son went Jimmy Dean as we called out the past is continue to invest heavily against. Lots of ROI there. And our intent is to get more brands to that same tradition over time, and it will be done by continuing to innovate and bring the investment up. So no guidance forward as where we think the ceiling is. What I would just say is as we start to see the progress, that we will get us closer to the top end of that range. We're going to invest to continue to have a strong, growing Prepared Foods business at those within range markets.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Terrific. And then just shifting gears, can you give us a little bit on the Chicken side of where you see your business evolving on the antibiotic-free side, both with nonhuman use antibiotics and total antibiotic-free chicken where you sort of
componenttext: All right. Terrific. And then just shifting gears, can you give us a little bit on the Chicken side of where you see your business evolving on the antibiotic-free side, both with nonhuman use antibiotics and total antibiotic-free chicken where you sort of plan to take the business over the next couple of years?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So far, we have announced last year, I think you've seen this, that we will be by the end of 2017, calendar 2017, our entire system will be with no antibiotics for use in human health. And we feel this is a really consumer-driven discussion. We have
componenttext: Yes. So far, we have announced last year, I think you've seen this, that we will be by the end of 2017, calendar 2017, our entire system will be with no antibiotics for use in human health. And we feel this is a really consumer-driven discussion. We have by no antibiotics ever products available today. We continue to be ahead of, frankly, executing our strategy that we've intended. And we will go where the consumer is. So in terms of what our supply chain is doing to support that, the message you should take away is we feel good about where we are. Actually, we're a bit ahead of where we thought we would be, and we'll continue to make progress to drive that agenda.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have our next question from Mr. Robert Moskow.
componenttext: We have our next question from Mr. Robert Moskow.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I think about the element of your business that has really outperformed the most and differentiated you, it's the value-added side of Chicken, and it's been an extraordinary achievement. But I think the challenge I have, and others maybe, is that when
componenttext: If I think about the element of your business that has really outperformed the most and differentiated you, it's the value-added side of Chicken, and it's been an extraordinary achievement. But I think the challenge I have, and others maybe, is that when you look at the components of what you define as value-add, it seems like it's a lot of products that could be easily duplicated by your competitors. And maybe they haven't set up the supply chain or the further processing capacity yet to do that. And I'm just wondering if you can help us a little bit with how many years ahead do you think you are versus competition. How -- what is it about the way you've set things up that makes it hard to duplicate? And just maybe help us think of it that way to understand the competitive advantage.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Rob. One are the things that we continue to come back to is those 5 elements that I talked about in my prepared remarks. Not commenting on competition, how quickly they come off the curve, I won't speak to that. But it's not any one thing. It's al
componenttext: Thanks, Rob. One are the things that we continue to come back to is those 5 elements that I talked about in my prepared remarks. Not commenting on competition, how quickly they come off the curve, I won't speak to that. But it's not any one thing. It's all those in combination that give our model the strength that it has. And the operations improvements, we don't typically talk a lot about, but it's been really, really impressive what we've done. And we're really thinking about what's the headline there, what have we done that is going to be notable or should be notable is that we feel the Chicken business is now in a spot where it's up Paul business phrases we're pushing supply on the market. So our pricing mechanisms reflect that. Our move to more value-added products, whether it's par-fried products, fully cut, we're building capacity against those because we continue to see tremendous demand. The buy-versus-grow strategy, we've talked a lot about. And then just staying on top of all those things that give us the best supply base that can make sure our customers are served excellently with great services is really what we're about. I don't know if that's satisfying you or not, but it's really -- those 5 things we talk about in combination. I can't point to any one that's going to be the silver bullet or the fantasy for that competes with us [indiscernible]. But that's what we continue to stay focused on.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016

componenttext: Maybe one follow-up, Tom. You're talking about increasing, I guess, your differentiation in tray pack. How revolutionary can you be there in what is a pretty basic-looking product?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, that -- we love consumer insights. So how revolutionary we can be will be dependent on what the consumer tells us. And where that takes us, we're sorting through right now. It's going to be an exciting time. There's a reason to believe that we shoul
componenttext: Well, that -- we love consumer insights. So how revolutionary we can be will be dependent on what the consumer tells us. And where that takes us, we're sorting through right now. It's going to be an exciting time. There's a reason to believe that we should not only I would say fresh, frankly, but also on the frozen case, be doing things that will be above and beyond what people are thinking about today based on what consumers are telling us. We'll really double down on those consumer insights. Probably not the way since the end it's under anybody our innovation team. So we'll talk about more about that, whether it's at CAGNY or other events. That's something that really going to be continuously focused on, and we're excited to do that.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016

componenttext: We have our next question from Mr. Jeremy Scott.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wondering if you could unpack the Chicken margin performance. I think when we started the year, you were looking for chicken margins to exceed 10%. And as you've outperformed, that's obviously come up, and now we're looking for closer to 13, 14. I re
componenttext: Just wondering if you could unpack the Chicken margin performance. I think when we started the year, you were looking for chicken margins to exceed 10%. And as you've outperformed, that's obviously come up, and now we're looking for closer to 13, 14. I realize there's a lot of moving parts, and I don't mean to oversimplify, but if we were to isolate the margins you were able to deliver from growing and selling chicken from the margins on your buy-in platforms, under the current conditions, is it reasonable to assume that the buy-versus-grow model is delivering a margin premium somewhere around 300, 200 bps just based on your change in guidance? And what's implicit in the fiscal '17 guidance? Is that level of premium achievable in the market only when there's a significant excess supply of breast meat?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I wouldn't say that, Jeremy. We couldn't describe any certain amount of basis points that are going to drive any one part of the model. What I would say is as we talked about our margins prospectively into '17, we feel like we're going to be about th
componenttext: Yes, I wouldn't say that, Jeremy. We couldn't describe any certain amount of basis points that are going to drive any one part of the model. What I would say is as we talked about our margins prospectively into '17, we feel like we're going to be about the same as '16. The idea that we have done things like we don't have unprotected fixed prices. We continue to drive our business throughout the channels that we have access to. There's a lot of reasons to be happy with the model that we have here at Tyson as it relates to chicken because we aren't just a one-trick pony. We have a lot of focus channels that we do really well and and we're continuing to drive our expertise in those category captaincies. We're up [ph] 143. I mean, which is not double from where we were at the time of the acquisition. Things that we're working with our customers to get to a better place, those are the things that we'll focus on. Grains, we've looked to this have the same margins, whether it's up or down and they're going to have some periods of time based on the slope of the curve. That, of course, is going to attack margins, but on balance, we look to make sure that we run our model with no excess. And that's where we've been, and that's what's been the driver of our success.

componenttext: Just curious about your pricing investments in Prepared Foods. You spoke about betting getting the gaps rate. componenttextpreview: We think the volume growth -- it depends on which category you're talking about. The overall Core 9, as we talked about, has been -- has done really, really well. Can't speak to what our competition's going to do. Certainly, we have predictive models base
componenttext: We think the volume growth -- it depends on which category you're talking about. The overall Core 9, as we talked about, has been -- has done really, really well. Can't speak to what our competition's going to do. Certainly, we have predictive models based on what input costs are doing. Than we think we're pretty good about understanding where they would go in a rational environment. We can't -- what are very good at predicting rational behavior. But I think competitors are going to act rationally. We have a pretty good bead on where we should be doing in terms of investing against our brand. The idea that this has done a great job for us, we continue to stay focused on. Where are the right level and where are the right gaps? Frankly, we're under the fall of last year, gaps became such that it was that your mental to the volume business. And like I said, earlier, want to make sure that we're in the right spot as we go into this 2017 with protein that's going to be available, and we want to make sure that we are available on shelf and we have the primary position. So that answers your question. But we feel we're in the right spot right now based on the investments that we've made.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, it's Tom. So what I'd say is the -- we don't say there's going to be a certain level that we would top out at necessarily in terms of investment. It's going to be -- I mean use example of every brand came up to the ROI that we get on Jimmy Dean acros
componenttext: Ken, it's Tom. So what I'd say is the -- we don't say there's going to be a certain level that we would top out at necessarily in terms of investment. It's going to be -- I mean use example of every brand came up to the ROI that we get on Jimmy Dean across the Core 9, we'd be spending a lot more and we'd be getting fantastic return for it. The model, what that looks like across every single property, we haven't necessarily done that, I would say. The idea was continuing to invest when we get the margin structure that we have and it continues to get better, we will put in the gap. The ideas we will not find ourselves in a position we think we're stopping the investment because we feel like it's going to be way too high. We generally focus on our investments, continue to go north on our branded products. But where that ceiling is, it's really something I can't comment on right now.

componenttext: Okay. And then my next question is, as you move to the Chicken business going to more of Prepared Foods and more value-added, if corn were to be at $1, $1.50 higher than this, would that have any impact on your margin outlook for 2017 and beyond?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 08, 2016

componenttext: No, I wouldn't say. I would say no. Really, it's -- for us, it's more about the slope of the curve. So it's not whether or not it's going to be at a certain sustained level or not. It's how quickly we go up or down. And that certainly affects all of our business, right, not just poultry. So that's -- we feel like our model is in a much better position because we have a value-added mix. We have the pricing mechanisms that don't change all at once. And so we feel like we're in a really good spot there.
