componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Tyson Foods Quarterly Investor Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] Please note, this event is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Jon Kathol, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to the Tyson Foods, Inc. Fourth Quarter and 2016 Fiscal Year Earnings Conference Call. On today's call are: Donnie Smith, Chief Executive Officer; Tom Hayes, President; and Dennis Leatherby, Executive Vice President and Chief Fin
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Tyson Foods, Inc. Fourth Quarter and 2016 Fiscal Year Earnings Conference Call. On today's call are: Donnie Smith, Chief Executive Officer; Tom Hayes, President; and Dennis Leatherby, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. 
Slides accompanying today's prepared remarks are available as a quarterly supplemental report on the Investor Relations section of our website at ir.tyson.com. Tyson Foods issued an earnings news release this morning, which has been filed with the SEC on Form 8-K and also is available on our website at ir.tyson.com. 
Our remarks today include forward-looking statements as defined in the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These statements reflect current views with respect to future events, such as Tyson's outlook for future performance on sales, margin, earnings growth and various other aspects of its business. These statements are subject to risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations and projections. I encourage you to read the release issued earlier this morning and our filings with the SEC for a discussion of the risks that can affect our business. 
During the call, there will be a discussion of some items that do not conform to U.S. generally accepted accounting principles, or GAAP, including adjusted EPS. Tyson has reconciled these items to the most comparable GAAP measures in the earnings release and on our website at ir.tyson.com. 
I would like to remind everyone that this call is being recorded on Monday, November 21, 2016, at 9 a.m., Eastern Time. A replay of today's call will be available on Tyson's website approximately 1 hour after the conclusion of this call. This broadcast is the property of Tyson Foods. And any redistribution, retransmission or rebroadcast of this call in any form without the expressed written consent of Tyson Foods is strictly prohibited. 
I'll now turn the call over to Donnie Smith.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jon. Good morning, everyone, and thanks joining us today. Before we get into our earnings discussion, I'd like to comment on this morning's other announcement. As you may have heard, Tom Hayes will be succeeding me as CEO effective at calendar yea
componenttext:
Thanks, Jon. Good morning, everyone, and thanks joining us today. Before we get into our earnings discussion, I'd like to comment on this morning's other announcement. As you may have heard, Tom Hayes will be succeeding me as CEO effective at calendar year-end. 
The board and I agree that now is the excellent time to make this transition. The company's performing exceptionally well and realizing significant growth and shareholder returns through our hybrid strategy of branded prepared foods and fresh meats. Simply put, I believe the company has a bright future and that Tom is the right leader for this next phase of our development. We've worked hard to create a strong platform that will take Tyson into the future and we have an impressive pipeline of talented management to help us do that. We're leveraging scale, developing our brands and building value for shareholders. 
Since his promotion to President earlier this year, Tom has reminded me, the board and the rest of the management team on a daily basis exactly why we hold him in such high regard. He's a capable leader, a strategic thinker and a team player who's ready to build on what we've accomplished to date and drive this company forward. He has the skills to deliver on our strategic goals and complete the transition toward our hybrid model. I've committed to him I will remain available as consultant for the next 3 years. 
As you can imagine, it's a time of mixed emotions for me. I joined Tyson Foods 36 years ago and has spent my entire professional life here. In return, I've been given opportunities I could never have imagined. At Tyson, I have worked alongside some of the best, most impressive people you could ever hope to meet. And together, we worked tirelessly to build a great company. I'd like to thank both the board and the Tyson family for their encouragement and support, without which I could have not succeeded. More than just delivering good financial results, we've been able to make a positive difference in people's lives. I'm thankful for the 7 years I had the opportunity to serve Tyson as its CEO. And I'm excited about its future and confident that Tom is the right leader for the next chapter. 
And with that, let's now turn to the quarter. Fiscal 2016 was our fourth consecutive year of record results with record operating income, operating margin, adjusted EPS, cash flow, Pork segment margins and Prepared Foods segment margins. Adjusted EPS grew 39% versus the prior year. Using the midpoint of our fiscal 2017 guidance of $4.70 to $4.85, the projected EPS 5-year CAGR would be 19%, which is outstanding. 
Fourth quarter results were slightly below our internal expectations, impacted largely by $35 million or $0.06 a share in mark-to-market and lower cost of market accounting treatments, primarily in Beef and Pork, a production issue in Prepared Foods and one-time factors in Chicken that Tom will go into in more detail shortly. 
Synergies for the fourth quarter were $165 million with $67 million incremental over Q4 of last year. Synergies for the year were $580 million with $258 million incremental to last year and well exceeding our $500 million target. We currently expect synergies of approximately $675 million in fiscal 2017, below our previous estimate of $700 million. While we still expect to achieve at least $700 million in total, due to the timing of some projects, we now expect some of the synergies to fall into fiscal '18. 
We bought back 8.3 million shares of stock for $600 million in Q4, excluding repurchases to offset dilution from equity compensation. For the fiscal year, share repurchases totaled 28.2 million for $1.7 billion. We were able to repurchase this level due to our record operating cash flows of more than $2.7 billion. 
2016 was a great year. Beyond setting records, we made tremendous progress, leveraging the combined strength of the Tyson team. And we're well positioned for even more success in fiscal '17. 
Now let's go to Tom for a report on our operating segments.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks a lot, Donnie. Let's begin with the Prepared Foods segment. Operating income in the fourth quarter was $133 million with a 7.2% operating margin. Average price was down 3.9%, primarily reflecting the pass-through of overall lower raw material costs
componenttext:
Thanks a lot, Donnie. Let's begin with the Prepared Foods segment. Operating income in the fourth quarter was $133 million with a 7.2% operating margin. Average price was down 3.9%, primarily reflecting the pass-through of overall lower raw material costs. Adjusting for the additional week in 2015, volume compared to Q4 last year was up 2.6%. Margin in the Prepared Foods segment were lower year-over-year primarily due to a sharp increase in pork and raw material costs in Q4 that were not passed through to customers within the quarter and increased marketing spending. 
In the foodservice portion of Prepared Foods in Q4, we had strong results in our bakery business but softer-than-expected results in prepared meats. As a part of our efforts to improve our production network, we closed a plant and transferred production to newer facilities. Unfortunately, this transition wasn't seamless, causing us to incur overtime in our operations and higher distribution costs in an attempt to satisfy our customers' needs. We've since taken steps to improve production efficiency and are building additional network capacity for long-term growth. 
Despite these challenges, Prepared Foods had a record year and delivered planned synergies. Synergies for the segment were $119 million for the quarter and $38 million incremental to Q4 last year. For the full year, Prepared Foods synergies were $441 million with $156 million incremental to fiscal 2015. For the fiscal year, Prepared Foods operating income was $734 million with a record 10% margin. Pricing was down 3.4% on lower raw materials. Adjusted volume was down 1% for the year, primarily due to the rationalization of some unprofitable ingredient meat SKUs. We're growing volume where we want to grow by focusing on strategic brands and categories to increase operating income over time. 
We supported our brand equities across Prepared Foods through marketing, advertising and promotional spending to grow volume and secure our position on the shelves of retailers and restaurants. For example, we increased our support behind the Jimmy Dean frozen breakfast franchise and Hillshire Farm lunchmeat. And in our fourth quarter, volume was up 9% and 28%, respectively. We also grew our share by 1.5 points in the Frozen Protein Breakfast category and by 2.3 points in lunchmeat. We expect beef and pork raw material to be deflationary to input cost in addition to pricing in 2017. We'll continue to invest in innovation, new product launches and MAP to grow our brands. We're expecting margins in 2017 to be similar to those in 2016 with solid volume growth that outperforms the categories where we compete. 
In the Chicken segment for the fourth quarter, operating income was $220 million with a 7.8% operating margin. Adjusted volume was down 3.2% due to a planned temporary decrease in production. And average price was up 3.5% as we focused on selling higher-margin products. There were 3 factors leading to lower-than-expected results in the fourth quarter in Chicken. 
First, our production forecasts are based on consumer demand. And through our sales and operations planning process, we received indications of lower demand in July and August. As our business model dictates, we reduced production in response to softening consumer demand. Secondly, we absorbed a sharp spike in soybean milk input costs within the quarter that affected margins in the short term. And third, having completed the restaging of the Tyson brand, we turned MAP back on to grow points of distribution, heading into the new fiscal year. As a result, our Tyson brand frozen and value-added chicken volume was up 6% in Q4 of 2016 and is gaining momentum, portending very strong Chicken segment volume in our first quarter of 2017. 
Chicken segment results for the year were outstanding. With an 11.9% operating margin, we were just shy of last year's record return. Operating income was $1.3 billion. Adjusted volume was down 0.7% due to the reduced demand in the fourth quarter that I just spoke to. Average pricing was down for the year by 1.5% as some input cost deflation was passed on to the customers. 
The USDA is now projecting for chicken supply to be in the U.S. to increase by 2% in 2017. And our input costs should be flat. We'll continue growing where we want to grow by selling more Tyson-branded value-added chicken. We expect the returns for the Chicken segment to be at or above the upper end of our normalized range of 9% to 11% again in fiscal 2017. 
Moving on to the Beef segment. Operating income was $139 million in Q4 with a 4% operating margin. Adjusted volume was down slightly by 0.3% while average sales price declined 14.9%, reflecting reduced cattle costs. For the fiscal year, operating income was $347 million with a 2.4% operating margin. Adjusted volume was up slightly by 0.8% while pricing declined 14.9%, again on lower cattle costs. Following a rocky start to the year, the Beef segment finished strong with favorable pricing environment continuing into our Q1. We're expecting our Beef margin to be at the upper end of its normalized range of 1.5% to 3% in fiscal '17, reflecting the favorable environment that we expect to continue for some time. 
I'll wrap up the segment performance by recapping the Pork segment results. Operating income was $108 million with an 8.7% operating margin. Adjusted volume was up slightly at 0.4% while average pricing was up 1% in the quarter. For the year, operating income was $528 million with a record 10.8% margin. Excluding the additional week in fiscal 2015 and the divestiture of our Heinold business in Q1 of last year, Pork volume was up 1.2% and average price was down 4.4%, reflecting lower hog costs. 
In fiscal 2017, we expect the favorable operating environment to continue and are estimating operating margin of at least 10% for the year. Currently, the USDA is projecting supplies of our protein categories to be up 2% to 3% next year with moderate export growth. Domestic demand for protein has been strong. And we expect it will continue in a deflationary environment. And we're very well positioned across all proteins and customer channels to respond to the changing demands of consumers. 
We're making significant investments in consumer insights, innovation, our brands, our customer relationships, our facilities and our people. In addition to $1 billion in CapEx in '17, we're investing on improving safety, animal well-being, warehousing and distribution and attracting and retaining talent throughout the organization. These investments should improve costs and turnover as well as continue to drive long-term sustainable growth. 
While protein demand overall is strong and growing, we're seeing a shift in how consumers spend, specifically in retail. When beef prices decline, more consumers buy beef as relative price premium versus other forms of protein narrows. This interaction is especially pronounced in the dynamic between ground beef and hot dogs. While the hot dog category overall was down in the 13 weeks ended October 2, we grew Ball Park volume by 11% and increased volume of share by 2.5 points. This is a great example of the power of a strong, leading brand like Ball Park and the consumer loyalty and strong customer support it garners. 
Overall, Tyson Foods is performing very well at retail. In the 13-week period roughly corresponding with our fourth quarter, our Core 9 product lines grew dollar share in all 9 categories and grew volume share in 8 of 9 categories. In total, we grew volume 9.6%, 8 points ahead of total food and beverage. If you take a look at the slides that we posted online, you'll see that both the Core 9 and total Tyson at retail are outpacing growth among the top 10 branded food-only companies in both sales and volume dollars. 
In sales volume, Tyson is only 1 of 3 companies that posted positive volume growth. In sales dollars, we are the only company to show positive growth with a 4.7% in the Core 9 and 2.1% overall. And that's in a deflationary protein pricing environment. I want to extend my congratulations to Andy Callahan and the entire retail package brands team for their outstanding performance. 
Turning to the foodservice channel. Traffic remains roughly flat and growth is driven by average check size, which is up about 2%. That was the case in calendar year 2015 and thus far in 2016 and is expected to continue through 2017. And despite a lackluster environment, Tyson Foods is doing well at foodservice. 
Our insights team, using data provided by NPD, has developed analytic tools that give us a better look in the broad line distribution sector within foodservice. Broad line distribution has long been an important channel to us. But now we're getting a better perspective on the role we play, the importance of value-added chickens and the strength of the Tyson brand. For the 52 weeks ended in July, the most recent data available, our volume grew 3.9%, more than double the category growth rate. By far, Tyson is the largest brand with a 33% share and growing. The next closest competitor is private label with a 20% share. 
And it's worth noting, we're a substantial producer of private label value-added chicken for our distributor customers. We look forward to being able to give you more and more insight into our foodservice business as our insights team continues to build out more analytic tools, which is a great example of the strength of our combined capabilities across the company. 
I continue to be encouraged by the pace of new product innovation as we extend our brands into adjacencies. Sales from new products launched in the previous 3 years has resulted in a Vitality Index of 14% in retail and 21% in foodservice. When we think about innovation, it's not only about new products. It really starts to understand how people shop and how shopper behavior opens up new platforms for innovation. 
Partnering with our customers to leverage the opportunities of the e-commerce space is a great example of this. We began selling Tyson Tastemaker meal kits through e-commerce in September. While it's still early, we're very encouraged by the initial consumer acceptance and feedback. This platform combines our innovation capabilities, supply chain at scale and leading brands in a way no other food company can. Expect to hear more in 2017 as we extend this platform into multiple formats in e-commerce and traditional retail. 
2016 was a great year. But more importantly, we laid the foundation for 2017 and beyond. We're capitalizing on our momentum and taking a systematic approach to success. 
Now I'm going to turn it over to Dennis, who will report on the fourth quarter and the year as well as our expectations for fiscal 2017.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom, and good morning, everyone. Fiscal '16 was our fourth consecutive year of record earnings as we continue to demonstrate the power of our diversified business model, producing strong, stable margins. We are investing our cash flows back into o
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom, and good morning, everyone. Fiscal '16 was our fourth consecutive year of record earnings as we continue to demonstrate the power of our diversified business model, producing strong, stable margins. We are investing our cash flows back into our businesses as we focus on long-term sustainable growth. 
Total company return on sales was a record 7.7% for fiscal '16. Operating income was also a record at $2.8 billion, representing a 26% increase over adjusted operating income a year ago. On an adjusted basis, this represents our fourth consecutive year of growth in operating income and return on sales. Our record adjusted EPS of $4.39 represents a 39% increase over $3.15 per share last year. Our operating cash flow was a record $2.7 billion. And we have invested $695 million in capital expenditures. This outpaced our depreciation by $78 million as we continue to invest in projects with a focus on delivering high ROIC. 
We also used our record cash flow in fiscal '16 to return cash to shareholders and to retire debt. We increased the dividend for fiscal '16 by 50% from the prior year. We also repurchased 28.2 million shares for $1.7 billion during the year. Combined, we returned over $1.9 billion to shareholders in share repurchases and dividends. And that's after we retired to some high-coupon debt during the year, which further strengthened our balance sheet. 
In fiscal '16, our effective tax rate was 31.8% and on an adjusted basis was 33.8%. Net debt-to-EBITDA for the past 12 months was 1.7x. Including cash of $349 million, net debt was $5.9 billion and total liquidity was $1.3 billion. Net interest expense was $57 million during the fourth quarter and $243 million during fiscal 2016. For the quarter, average diluted shares outstanding were 381 million. ROIC was 18.1% and is approaching the pre-Hillshire acquisition level of 20.5%, which illustrates the strength and stability of our earnings as well as our commitment to creating incremental shareholder value. 
Now looking forward, here are some thoughts on fiscal '17. We expect similar revenues as we grow volume across each segment, offset by the impact of lower beef prices. Net interest expense should approximate $225 million. We currently estimate our effective tax rate to be around 35%. CapEx is expected to approximate $1 billion as we focus on capacity expansion and operational improvements that create long-term shareholder value. Prior to adjusting for any additional share repurchases subsequent to this call and based on our average share price so far in Q1, we expect our average diluted shares to be around 376 million. 
This morning, we reported our Board of Directors again increased our regular quarterly dividend by another 50% from $0.15 to $0.225 per share on our Class A common stock payable on December 15. This increase brings our dividend to $0.90 per share annually for Class A shares from $0.60. As we stated last year, we expect to increase future dividends for Class A shares by at least $0.10 per share annually. This increase and our commitment to steady future dividend increases demonstrates our confidence in the enduring strength and stability of our cash-generation capabilities. 
We have a tremendous amount of momentum going into fiscal '17 as we come off a year of 39% EPS growth. Our fiscal first quarter in '17 is off to a phenomenal start, which gives us confidence in achieving annual adjusted EPS growth of 7% to 10% to a range of $4.70 to $4.85 per share. This new guidance range represents a 5-year adjusted compounded annual growth rate of at least 19%. While we are pleased with the growth we have achieved, we're excited about the significant increase in investments in fiscal '17 that will drive growth of the future. In addition to $1 billion in CapEx, we are planning heavy investments, as Tom mentioned previously, while we continue to grow organically. 
Additionally, in fiscal '17, we expect to return even more cash to shareholders by our announced increased dividend and additional share repurchases. We see compelling value in our shares. And so far in the first quarter of fiscal '17, we've repurchased another 3.4 million shares for $240 million. While some of our investments will not immediately fall to the bottom line, we are creating a sustainable blueprint for success that will allow us to grow in a responsible way for the future. 
In closing, we take a long-term view toward investing in our people, our brands and our facilities, which will drive value and generate attractive shareholder returns. That concludes our prepared remarks. Denise, we're ready to begin Q&A.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And your first question will come from Ken Zaslow of BMO Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And your first question will come from Ken Zaslow of BMO Capital Markets.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Donnie, congratulations, it's been a pleasure and I wish you well. And Tom, congratulations on your promotion, I think. With that, Donnie, I have to say your timing of your retirement may not be perceived as optimal. Tyson is in the middle of a class acti
componenttext: Donnie, congratulations, it's been a pleasure and I wish you well. And Tom, congratulations on your promotion, I think. With that, Donnie, I have to say your timing of your retirement may not be perceived as optimal. Tyson is in the middle of a class action suit. Earnings fell short of expectations on the perception that you've kind of reached peak earnings. And you're in a debate over your Georgia Dock pricing, it seems like. So let me just tackle one issue at a time. Why not hand the reins over once the dust settles a little bit? Second, how much of the earnings shortfall in the quarter will be recaptured in the first quarter? Third, if Georgia Dock prices go away, how much would Tyson's outlook actually change? And then Dennis, just to kind of go back on this, on the share repurchases, given that your stock seems to be probably pricing down at least 10% to 15% today, what is the expectation for share repurchases going into this first quarter?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So I'm going to take the first one of that, and then Tom and Dennis will start from there. Ken, I think this is an excellent time for us to be making this transition. The company is off to a phenomenal start for the quarter. We're on a very solid fo
componenttext: Okay. So I'm going to take the first one of that, and then Tom and Dennis will start from there. Ken, I think this is an excellent time for us to be making this transition. The company is off to a phenomenal start for the quarter. We're on a very solid foundation. As we've said before, we dispute the claims. We're looking forward to our opportunity to defending ourselves in court on the litigation. So that has nothing to do with the transition. So yes, there's not a better time. We've got a great team. Tom is a very capable leader. So in terms of all of that, there couldn't be a better time to be making this transition. Now Tom, I'll let you start on the second, third and fourth.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So thanks, Ken. And what I'll say is the timing, I think, from everybody's perspective actually couldn't be better, given the great shape Donnie has brought the company to. And we are all just thrilled about the opportunities ahead of us. As it relat
componenttext: Yes. So thanks, Ken. And what I'll say is the timing, I think, from everybody's perspective actually couldn't be better, given the great shape Donnie has brought the company to. And we are all just thrilled about the opportunities ahead of us. As it relates to the Q4 to Q1, yes, there's shortfall in Q1. And I think largely you'll see it show up in a strong -- our Q4 show up in Q1. So the lower [indiscernible] results in Prepared Foods and Chicken certainly relates to MAP spending that I spoke to. But I think we're in a great shape, particularly in Beef and Pork, which I think shouldn't surprise you. As it relates to the Georgia Dock, this is what we talked about before several times is that we really don't use it that much. It's about 4%, maybe a little less our total Chicken volume sales that are priced off the Georgia dock. We have talked several times that we use a lot of different pricing mechanisms. And we are diversified. We don't feel like it has a significant impact to us. But the Georgia Dock has had very little influence on our pricing strategy. And Dennis, I don't know if you want to add...

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: As far as the share repurchases go, Ken, on that question, last quarter, we bought $600 million worth of stock. We've bought $240 million so far. And we have a phenomenal quarter going and we -- which means heavy cash flow. So you can expect we'll have an
componenttext: As far as the share repurchases go, Ken, on that question, last quarter, we bought $600 million worth of stock. We've bought $240 million so far. And we have a phenomenal quarter going and we -- which means heavy cash flow. So you can expect we'll have another big quarter. I won't get into the exact number, but we'll buy quite a bit of stock back.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to be clear. So how much of -- just making sure I get the answers. How much of your earnings shortfall will come back in the first quarter? And then if Georgia Dock prices go completely away, will that have any impact on Tyson's outlook?
componenttext: Just to be clear. So how much of -- just making sure I get the answers. How much of your earnings shortfall will come back in the first quarter? And then if Georgia Dock prices go completely away, will that have any impact on Tyson's outlook?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: As far as the earnings going into this quarter, all of it will come back into the quarter from a shortfall standpoint. As far as the Georgia Dock goes, how much it will impact, it will have no impact if Georgia Dock went away.
componenttext: As far as the earnings going into this quarter, all of it will come back into the quarter from a shortfall standpoint. As far as the Georgia Dock goes, how much it will impact, it will have no impact if Georgia Dock went away.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question will come from Jeremy Scott of CLSA.
componenttext: And the next question will come from Jeremy Scott of CLSA.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Appreciate some of the clarity there, and congratulations, Donnie and Tom. I'll echo that but also echo some of the surprise maybe at the timing. Just to follow up on the Georgia Dock, can you repeat what percentage of your sales are tied to the Georgia D
componenttext: Appreciate some of the clarity there, and congratulations, Donnie and Tom. I'll echo that but also echo some of the surprise maybe at the timing. Just to follow up on the Georgia Dock, can you repeat what percentage of your sales are tied to the Georgia Dock? And then secondly, can all of your clients that are pricing on Georgia Dock without restriction or penalty opt to price on the index other than Georgia Dock theoretically right now?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So to repeat, it's about 4%, maybe 3.5% to 4% of our total Chicken sales off the Georgia Dock. And customers can negotiate to price it off at whatever index they would like. What we have found is that's not a good proxy for cost. And we have some ver
componenttext: Yes. So to repeat, it's about 4%, maybe 3.5% to 4% of our total Chicken sales off the Georgia Dock. And customers can negotiate to price it off at whatever index they would like. What we have found is that's not a good proxy for cost. And we have some very sophisticated buyers that tend to look more at grain input than they do of the Georgia Dock. Certainly, it's got a lot of history and it's something that's been around for a while. But we find increasingly our customers are looking to have discussions about where do they think grain is. And then in addition to that, I'd say there's a lot of discussion which we've also spoken about this. It's less about price than it is about everything else we offer as a company. And we're getting more and more into those discussions frankly and less and less about the absolute price of input costs. So yes, I don't know if that answers your question, but that is the way we think about it it. It's a very, very, very small part of what we do.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just wanted to ask about Chicken again, obviously a big surprise miss in the quarter. Didn't really add up to any of our models. I appreciate the 3 factors that you flagged. Can you quantify them in terms of what were the impact on margins of ea
componenttext: Okay. And just wanted to ask about Chicken again, obviously a big surprise miss in the quarter. Didn't really add up to any of our models. I appreciate the 3 factors that you flagged. Can you quantify them in terms of what were the impact on margins of each factor? And what -- how they will roll over into the first quarter?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I won't go through the specific impact of each one. What I will say is the soybean mill market went up, we were probably less hedged. As we go towards the end of the year, we're looking for the new crop. That is something that certainly if there a
componenttext: Yes. So I won't go through the specific impact of each one. What I will say is the soybean mill market went up, we were probably less hedged. As we go towards the end of the year, we're looking for the new crop. That is something that certainly if there are spikes, is going to play through our numbers. As we go through our negotiation with customers, we look to capture everything that we can. We have I think in the last call we've talked about severe runoffs the slope of the curve is high. We have a harder time passing through those costs to our customers. So that was certainly a big impact.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 21, 2016

componenttext: And just to reiterate, Jeremy, we are saying that for the year that the earnings in chicken will be at or above the normalized range.

componenttext: Right.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just lastly on the CapEx, what exactly is driving the incremental investment there. Talk about some of the initiatives that you are taking but can you break that down into pieces?
componenttext: Okay. And then just lastly on the CapEx, what exactly is driving the incremental investment there. Talk about some of the initiatives that you are taking but can you break that down into pieces?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the biggest one is we are spending quite a bit of money to expand production at our plans got a lot of growth opportunities. I mentioned briefly in the prepared meats sector and foodservice, we have some capital spending there. We have increased o
componenttext: Yes. So the biggest one is we are spending quite a bit of money to expand production at our plans got a lot of growth opportunities. I mentioned briefly in the prepared meats sector and foodservice, we have some capital spending there. We have increased our spending against or increased our production capacity on cooked chicken, fully cooked chicken, and we're pretty close to being well through that capacity, and we need to build more. So think about the largest percentage of that will be focused on growth. And we have, in addition to that, we're spending to make sure the all of our processes are working well and a lot of sustainability efforts. But to answer your question, in CapEx, it's predominantly focused on growth.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 21, 2016

componenttext: In the last question will come from Adam Samuelson of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll echo Ken and Jeremy's comments. Donnie, congratulations and Tom, congratulations as well. Maybe my first question in Prepared Foods and just to be clear, on the margin guidance for fiscal '17 of 10%, basically flat margins year-over-year. Can you qua
componenttext: I'll echo Ken and Jeremy's comments. Donnie, congratulations and Tom, congratulations as well. Maybe my first question in Prepared Foods and just to be clear, on the margin guidance for fiscal '17 of 10%, basically flat margins year-over-year. Can you quantify both the fourth quarter seems like there were some production issues that you don't seem to be expecting to lap. There's still about $100 million of year-over-year synergies. You're growing your volumes strongly in your highest-margin value-added categories in the Core 9. And you've got some nice commodity deflation at your back. Can you talk about kind of the level of reinvestment spend in Prepared Foods that you wouldn't expect a sharper better margin leverage and/or kind of earnings improvement?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. We think about the -- ROS is flat, of course, ROI. But we think we want to make sure that we continue to do is focus on volume. Hopefully, in those charts were able those online, the investments are paying off, so we have significant investment goin
componenttext: Sure. We think about the -- ROS is flat, of course, ROI. But we think we want to make sure that we continue to do is focus on volume. Hopefully, in those charts were able those online, the investments are paying off, so we have significant investment going into not the least of which is MAP in Q4, there was a big impact in the rate. But then as you looked at what we're doing for preparing ourselves for the '17, it's all about making sure that we have the shelf space. We are driving innovation and we continue to invest and frankly, lift the investment in some of the categories that weren't ready for and some of the brands that weren't ready for the MAP spending as much as they are today. So we think in terms of the fourth quarter pretty much as we thought it would as we talked in the last call. We're executing that strategy that we want to be continually at 10%, and we did it in 2016. With more protein on the market next year, we want to make sure we're in a good position that I spoke to, and we want to continue to drive category growth for our customers. So we're continuing to invest significantly and growing where we want to grow, which is in the Core 9 as we demonstrate.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. then maybe switching gears to chicken and understanding that there were some issues in the fourth quarter that it doesn't sound like you think repeat maybe other than the MAP spending, you've guided margins at or above the high end o
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. then maybe switching gears to chicken and understanding that there were some issues in the fourth quarter that it doesn't sound like you think repeat maybe other than the MAP spending, you've guided margins at or above the high end of the 11% normalized range. Can you talk about kind of the bigger swing factors in chicken as you look out to fiscal through '17? I mean, the feed costs given the harvest that we just had what seemed to be fairly benign. It seems like you've got good mix tailwinds in terms of your value-added business. Export markets are okay. Can you talk about some of the bigger kind of drivers of variance of that you upper downside risks in chicken for the next 12 months?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I mean, you called it as it relates to the grain. We feel like that is pretty much flat will be in the same position in '17 as we are in '16 as far as we know today. What we continue to do is drive the core of that business up. So retail and foodser
componenttext: Sure. I mean, you called it as it relates to the grain. We feel like that is pretty much flat will be in the same position in '17 as we are in '16 as far as we know today. What we continue to do is drive the core of that business up. So retail and foodservice, value-added products and we drive the noncore, the commodity linked quarters and byproduct down. So roughly, the value-added products are up about 4%. The commodity products, down 7%. So the net is, if you look at the total, chicken platform is roughly flat, but the mix in between is continuing to improve towards value-added.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question will come from Robert Moskow of Credit Suisse.
componenttext: And the next question will come from Robert Moskow of Credit Suisse.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I thought also one of the comments about chicken was that you had expected chicken demand to be down in July, August, so you reduced production. And you said it was related to consumer demand. And I guess, that's related to lower beef prices. Was consumer
componenttext: I thought also one of the comments about chicken was that you had expected chicken demand to be down in July, August, so you reduced production. And you said it was related to consumer demand. And I guess, that's related to lower beef prices. Was consumer demand as weak as you thought it was for chicken? I mean, it seems to me the demand for chicken had been a huge part of the story overall. Are you seeing any kind of weakening in that regard? And then I had follow-up on trim prices, which we track. Other than a little bit of spike in July, you didn't see anything else for the quarter. In fact, they came down to quite a bit in August and September. So I wanted to maybe get a sense of just how sharp of an increase that was for your Prepared Foods margins.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Yes, as it relates to poultry first, the volume was softer for sure in Q4. So we saw it coming. We had a good S&OP process. We think it probably goodness we ever experience. And having those signals allows us to modify production in advance of seein
componenttext: Sure. Yes, as it relates to poultry first, the volume was softer for sure in Q4. So we saw it coming. We had a good S&OP process. We think it probably goodness we ever experience. And having those signals allows us to modify production in advance of seeing that now. As Dennis had said and talked about, we've seen that come back in the first quarter here. So the volume was off, and it now has come back. And the other thing that we want to make sure that we do is we have lower inventories. We want to make sure that we don't run into a seasonal high inventories, and that certainly helped us. We're selling through the inventory to a large degree in Q1. So there was the right thing to certainly pull back in production. As it relates to the trim pricing, so if you look at 72s and 42s trim for the Prepared Foods segment, and particularly as it relates to hotdogs and grain materials for sausage and so forth, there's a sharp spike and then I dropped off dramatically. As the trim is dropping off, we have it sit for us because crops are going down our prices up with a shoot up in any given period, the slope of the chains is going to cost us, particularly on the foodservice business for formula price that have our raw material costs higher, and our formula price is lagging by about 30 days. So that was a short-term impact. We're through that, but that's the situation there.

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And why do you think chicken demand is coming back? I mean, beef prices continue to fall, so you might see more consumer demand shifting to beef. I mean, what -- how do you know it's not just a head fake and it might get weak again?
componenttext: And why do you think chicken demand is coming back? I mean, beef prices continue to fall, so you might see more consumer demand shifting to beef. I mean, what -- how do you know it's not just a head fake and it might get weak again?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We see that the value that we provide through for all of our customers is predominately focused on how they grow their categories overall. And when you look at chicken, then we have significant MAP spending that we have. They want us to invest in the busi
componenttext: We see that the value that we provide through for all of our customers is predominately focused on how they grow their categories overall. And when you look at chicken, then we have significant MAP spending that we have. They want us to invest in the business and continues to drive growth. We have seen some certainly some share gains, and that's something that we're tremendously excited about. As we look at how chicken the retail value-added poultry or the Tyson brand at retail, it's been doing very well. We've got a lot of innovation behind it. So those are sort of the key drivers and some of the foodservice business that we picked up over the summer is starting. So there's a lot of things that I can't give you all the detail on it, Rob, but there's a lot of things that are sort of working together as they give us tremendous confidence about chicken volume, not just Q1 but for '17.

componenttext: Okay. With that in mind, can you help us and I know you're getting the same question in 10 different ways so forgive me, but can help us walk through the mechanics of that? Because I'm not quite sure to think the soy issue that doesn't reverse, right? MAP spending, I assume it's not coming down in the first quarter. I know that retail prices are always much less volatile. It just seems a little more so this time. They're really kind of being sticky. I'm just curious is what your updated thoughts are. If that changes when that might change are you having any conversations with your grocery customers about their profit prices that they should have on shelf at this point?

headline: Tyson Foods, Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 21, 2016

componenttext: Yes. We kind of ran that. We don't influence necessarily the price that they're going to be charging on the shelf. But you got nail the dynamic is that livestock prices have not come down faster than [indiscernible] prices, which is to make the margins that we have written on both beef and pork. So how that sticks through the season I think it remains to be seen, but that is the dynamic that's allowing us to have a very, very strong first quarter.

componenttext: Teak so thank you. Georgia dock is one of many of the element that we use. I would say that as we talked about in the past, probably the best for us is if we have something that's tied to any indices, it's really the underlying grains. So if you have a customer that's willing to lock for a period of time, then it's smart for us to a lock the grain that's underneath. So make sure we have a margin that's locked up. Beyond that, I would say continues to see our portfolio move more and more to what I'll call list pricing. List pricing with a promotional element on top of it. So regardless whether it's foodservice or retail, that's the model that we have it was in Prepared Foods. A lot of the chicken value-add acts like Prepared Foods. So I'd say that's the predominant model beyond locking it against a grain underlying input cost.
